TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before calling the honourable member for Mackellar, I point out that as a result of a ruling I gave last year I have had occasion to consider the question of motions for suspension of Standing Orders. It might be helpful if I were to inform the House of the position I intend to adopt in relation to motions seeking to suspend Standing Orders which are proposed without prior warning having been given to the House. Standing order 399 provides:

INTERJECT.PARA: In cases of necessity, any standing or sessional order or orders of the House may be suspended, on motion, duly moved and seconded, without notice: Provided that such motion is carried by an absolute majority of Members having full voting rights.

It should not be inferred from the standing order that a motion to suspend Standing Orders can be moved at any time, because it is a fundamental rule of parliamentary practice that any motion before the House must be disposed of, or debate on the motion adjourned, before another substantive motion can be moved. I refer to a substantive motion because honourable members will be aware that subsidiary motions which are largely procedural in character are often moved while a substantive motion is before the House; for example, a closure motion, a motion to adjourn the debate or the moving of an amendment.

If a motion to suspend Standing Orders moved pursuant to standing order 399 is relevant to a matter already before the House, it may be accepted by the Chair. However, if it is not relevant to a matter before the House it will be accepted only if it is moved between items of business. I take this opportunity to inform the House of that because this is the first opportunity I have had to do so. I call the honourable member for Mackellar to proceed with his motion.
Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the honourable member for Mackellar presenting forthwith the Health Legislation Amendment Bill of which he has given notice for the next sitting and moving that the Bill be now read a second time.

Today all doctors in New South Wales public hospitals have stopped work except for emergency procedures. At this very moment in New South Wales radiologists in the public hospitals are continuing an existing ban on all but urgent cases. Doctors in Sutherland Hospital decided to continue today's action beyond today. Canberra doctors have been on strike for two weeks. Doctors in Victorian public hospitals from today are banning paper work, refusing unpaid overtime and refusing less than schedule fee services. Doctors have indicated that because of the actions of this Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and this Government they intend to escalate this action this week and in succeeding weeks.

We want the suspension of Standing Orders to treat this matter as one of grave emergency because the public hospital system in Australia is in a state of grave crisis because of the actions of this Minister and the support of this Government for his stand. In the hospitals today we have a totally unnecessary crisis. The Minister for Health and the Government have provoked this crisis, and it is one which they are failing to resolve. Today the Minister brought forward what he said were some propitiatory signs, some concessions to the medical profession, because he had failed to get its agreement to introduce his Medicare system before it began.

He has introduced a minor concession only, a concession which he refused to acknowledge or accept when we put it forward in September last year. Therefore, the Opposition submits that the Government is unable to resolve the crisis in our hospitals. We regard it as essential that the Parliament resolve this crisis . We regard the private member's Bill, which I will speak to once the House agrees to the suspension of Standing Orders, as an essential component of the resolution of this grave crisis.

It is not enough for the Government to come forward with minor concessions which it knows to be unacceptable to the medical profession whilst patients in public hospitals, waiting for elective procedures, desperately concerned about their health, have to wait while this Government and this Minister come to the necessary conclusion as to the steps they have to take in order to resolve this situation. What have they been doing? Instead of attempting to resolve the situation the Government has allowed its Minister for Health day by day to provoke the doctors. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has compared the doctors to the Builders Labourers Federation. Indeed, the Minister for Health has said that this is being unkind to the Builders Labourers Federation.

This is the first strike the doctors have felt obliged to call in the whole history of the Australian medical profession. In the history of Australia we have seen various health changes. Each one of these has been preceded by discussions between the then Minister for Health, from whichever party is in government, Labor or Liberal. It has been possible to achieve consensus, even for socialist programs, with this profession. By contrast, this Minister not only has failed to get the profession's agreement to bring in these programs but also has provoked it to the point where it is taking action against the public interest.

The Opposition took all the necessary steps earlier during the debate to warn the Minister for Health that it would come to this pass if he proceeded with his action. He had good warning; he had good warning from the profession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member should relate his remarks to the reasons for the suspension of Standing Orders. He is conducting a more general debate.

—Mr Speaker, I have carefully refrained from arguing the subject matter of my private member's Bill. I have been addressing my remarks to the crisis which exists in the public hospitals which has been provoked by this Minister who could have avoided it had he accepted advice from the medical profession, from the Opposition, from the Australian Democrats and from everybody in the community who wants a sensible resolution of this crisis. The Minister has done the very reverse; he has not made the necessary concessions; he has not entered into reasonable discussions. He has been misleading in his intentions on his original proposals. Indeed he has compared the doctors, who have never been on strike before in Australia's history, with the Builders Labourers Federation. The Prime Minister has accused the doctors of behaving like the Builders Labourers Federation. The Prime Minister has provoked the doctors and instead of taking the conciliatory role, which he used to like taking when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, instead of taking a consensus position, which is the stated position of his Government, and instead of intervening at an appropriate moment when his Minister was making a total ass of himself and bringing the Australian hospital system to a standstill, he has compared the doctors with the Builders Labourers Federation. Two days later the Minister on television, in response to a question on whether he agreed with the Prime Minister, said that he thought that was being unkind to the Builders Labourers Federation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether this Government understands it but the success of its whole Medicare program depends on the providers of services and the doctors being free and able to co-operate with the Government in this process. That is the heart of the suspension of Standing Orders which I have moved today and what is behind the private member's Bill which I intend introducing into the House. Because of this provocation begun by the Minister and supported by the Prime Minister and the Government we have a situation in which the doctors have no confidence in this Minister, no confidence to negotiate satisfactorily, no confidence in his intentions and no confidence in his statements about what he is likely to do in the future. As a result of the way this Minister has handled this issue the doctors are fearful that he is trying to get around the constitutional provisions of section 51 of the Constitution which were put there in 1946. Those provisions were put into the Constitution at a time when doctors were fearful that there would be nationalisation of health in this country. The history behind that change is important. In this Parliament the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Menzies, suggested to the Government and to Dr Evatt that there should be inserted into the changes that the Labor Government was going to make to the Constitution in 1946 a provision which prevented civil conscription of doctors. That was accepted by Dr Evatt; it was put into the constitutional changes and was accepted by the Australian people.

Over the last six months the confidence that has been built up in the medical profession as to the good intentions of successive Federal governments has been eroded and almost destroyed by the actions of this Minister and this Government. That is at the heart of the Opposition's concern today. It is desperately concerned that the Parliament intervene by considering a private member's Bill which would eliminate the offending clauses of section 17 of the Health Insurance Act until such time as the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals, which has already been established by the Minister, could report, and so that the Minister could go back with a clean slate to negotiate with the doctors. It would then be possible for the Minister to do what he ought to have done before he introduced Medicare, that is, to have a sensible discussion with the doctors about his real intentions. His Medicare program could then continue as he believes it ought to.

There is no reason why the Government should have got into this position. There is every reason why this Parliament has to intervene. We in the Opposition insist that the Parliament debate the matter and that it take it out of the hands of this Minister. It ought to have been taken out of his hands by the Prime Minister, but the Prime Minister chose to pour petrol on the flames. The Prime Minister bears with the Minister for Health the responsibility for the crisis in our public hospital system. He bears joint responsibility. The Government as a whole bears this responsibility. The House must now take the responsibility to resolve this issue once and for all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I second the motion. On 1 February every taxpayer in Australia was called upon to pay a one per cent levy on his tax in order to meet the cost of Medicare. This is the first occasion that the Minister can tell us how he is going to put back in place a relationship which for so long has provided a very high standard of medical care and attention to the people of Australia.

Unless this House suspends Standing Orders to allow my colleague to present his Bill there is no way that every specialist will not feel that the intervention which this academic has provided is going to intrude in such a way that it will interrupt completely the availability of health services right across the spectrum. There is no doubt, from the meeting of the Doctors Reform Society at which the Minister for Health indicated that the diagnostic specialists are only first on the rank, that there is reason for the doctors of Australia to be concerned. While for the first time in the history of medical practice in Australia every one of them is now on strike, they are on strike because they validly have cause because of the intervention by government between the doctor and the patient.

There is no easier way for this House to resolve the whole matter than for it to consider my colleague's motion and his amending Bill which will ensure that the status of Medicare is put back so that the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals can be completed, so that we are in a position to know what might be the cost of diagnostic services and so that we can see whether in a process of proper negotiation we can have a regime which will ensure that neither the medicos nor the patients and the taxpayers are disadvantaged. There is no doubt that unless the Standing Orders are suspended all of the country patients around Australia who do not have the advantage of any consulting medicos will pay their one per cent levy for no Medicare benefits at all. Unless there is a suspension of Standing Orders to consider my colleague's Bill, there is no capability for the taxpayers of Australia to receive value for those dollars that they contribute. They are all in a position where they will know that the doctor-patient relationship which they have cherished-we are talking about privately insured patients-has been prejudiced by this scheme which is inadequate and is costing every taxpayer dearly even where the services are not now available.

Unless this House is now in a position to consider the Bill which my colleague will introduce and which will reinstate the provisions of the Act before the Medicare amendment was introduced, there will be no certainty that there can be any resolution of the conflict between doctors and government. The blame is on the Government. It is for the Government to consider this motion and put the situation back to where it was so that the doctors can consult with the Minister and the Minister will be forced to consult with them. Unless there is that reinstatement, there is no opportunity for fair dealings.

—I direct a question to the Prime Minister. I ask: In view of recent statements about the 1984-85 Budget deficit, by how much does the Prime Minister believe it is appropriate to reduce the deficit next year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has not made any decision about the size of the deficit for 1984-85, but I remind the House that ever since we introduced our first Budget in August of last year I have been saying consistently inside this place and outside that we would reduce the demands of this Government on the financial market as private investment increased during the economic recovery. Of course, the question, and it is an important question, is: How far can we go to reduce our demands on the financial markets and so ease pressures on interest rates without withdrawing so much stimulus from the economy that recovery and the incentive for private investment are curtailed for lack of demand? Striking the right balance between those two considerations requires a careful assessment of the prospects for recovery of private investment and of the pressures in the financial market in the next financial year.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is working towards a situation where there can be a responsible reduction in the deficit for next year. I say now that there will be such a reduction. We believe that there are certain factors operating which are relevant to this. We believe that the enlarged corporate profits which are already emerging resulting from a combination of both strong economic recovery and growth and from wage moderation within the limits of the accord will greatly increase the capacity of the corporate sector to finance investment out of its own resources. I assure the Parliament and the Government too --

—Order! I sometimes think the Leader of the Opposition wishes me to have to take action against him.

—The honourable member for Hume could undertake a much more serious inquisition into the problems of unemployment rather than being used by a television crew to show up what his problems may be by living on a small amount of money for one week. I suggest to that television crew that there are literally hundreds of thousands of stories of poverty in this country that should be examined by the media and that are not being examined, apart from the exercise of following the honourable member on his push bike for a week in Canberra. I do not think the honourable member does himself or the Parliament justice in carrying out this exercise.

ANSWER.PARA: A quick check of the records will show that over the last four years in this Parliament the honourable member for Hume has never spoken about or asked a question on unemployment. Therefore, his seriousness about this subject can be called into question. Honourable members may recall that on something like 11 occasions during that period the then Labor Opposition moved motions in this Parliament to have the Parliament look at the problems being caused in this country by unemployment. This subject deserves to be treated seriously by this Parliament and by those people who have the enormous privilege of serving in this Parliament. That includes the honourable member for Hume, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) and every other honourable member in this House. I suggest to the honourable member for Hume that if he were seriously to reconsider his position he would withdraw from the exercise he has undertaken.

PETITION.TITLE: Chiropractic Services
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Chiropractic Services
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows-
That, with the exception of the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory, all State Parliaments have enacted chiropractic legislation.
That chiropractors provide a safe, effective and economical health care service that is complementary to medicine.

That the introduction of a Federally funded health care system restricted to the services provided almost exclusively by the medical profession restricts the freedom to select the health care practitioner of one's choice and does nothing to reduce the high cost of health care in Australia.
That a financial disadvantage will be incurred by those citizens utilizing chiropractic care, many of whom find that their health complaints do not respond satisfactorily to traditional approaches.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled ensures that chiropractic services are included in Medicare when it is introduced.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Baldwin,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Cadman,Mrs Child,Mrs Darling,Mr Fisher,Mr Groom,Mr Hawker,Mr Porter,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Rocher and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: National Life and Democratic Institutions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth: That we, the loyal citizens of Australia firmly express our strong opposition to any proposals to remove or undermine the importance of the place of God and/or the Queen in our national life, and democratic institutions.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Parliament assembled reaffirm our nation's total dependence on God the Creator in accordance with our Australian Constitution, which commences with the words 'Humbly relying on the blessing of Almighty God', and the Standing Orders of both the Senate and the House of Representatives which precribe that Parliament each day shall open with a special prayer to Almighty God and the Lord's Prayer.
We also call on the Parliament assembled to re-affirm our genuine loyalty to our Head of State, the Queen of Australia, Elizabeth II-'God save the Queen',
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite,Mr Fife,Mr O'Keefe and Mr Sinclair.

PETITION.TITLE: Kangaroos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully sheweth their desire to stop the commercial exploitation of the kangaroo.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House re-apply the ban on the export of kangaroo products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Blanchard,Mr Brumby and Mrs Darling.

PETITION.TITLE: Omega Base
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that.

1. Omega by sending low frequency signals, penetrating sea water enables hunter -killer submarines to establish their position and to launch a 'first strike' attack. Omega is also used by AWACs, the flying radar stations, and for other military purposes.
2. Omega is an important U.S. military base and a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Omega would have a disastrous effect on Victoria and Melbourne .
3. Omega and other U.S. bases in Australia endanger, rather than protect us. They add a new unnecessary menace to a nuclear arms race that must be stopped, if we are to survive.
Your petitioners pray that members and the House assembled will close Omega.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child and Mr Milton.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting and Television Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That because television and radio
(a) affect our social and moral environment,
(b) are family media watched and heard by many children at all times, and
(c) present too much explicit violence and sex,
they therefore need stronger control than other media and the existing standards need stricter enforcement in both national A.B.C., and commercial sectors.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That the Australian Government will amend the Broadcasting and Television Act, in relation to both national and commercial broadcasters, to legislate
(a) for adequate and comprehensive programs in the best interests of the general public,
(b) for a 'Dual System of Regulation' enforced by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by internal regulation and external control.
(c) for an independent consumer body to represent the best interests of the general public, and
(d) for immediate and effective penalties to be imposed for breaches of program and advertising standards.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife and Mr Hollis.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens, parents and teachers working for and in the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia, respectfully showeth that:
We support the Federal Government's determination to restore the community's confidence in public education.

We support the Federal Government's opposition to base grants to all non- government schools (a) by reducing funds to those schools already operating above community standards and (b) funding other schools according to need.
We support the Federal Government's policy of negotiations and planning with State/Territory Governments regarding joint programmes for improvements in Government Schools in the next decade.
1. We ask that the Federal Government increase recurrent funding for government schools as promised.
2. We ask that the Federal Government provide promised funding for special programmes to assist primary children with learning difficulties.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hayden and Mrs Kelly.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights in the Soviet Union
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia shows that the Soviet Union continues to violate human rights in Latvia. This is clearly demonstrated by the recent case of Janis Rozkalns, a practising Baptist who, on January 6, 1983, had his house forcibly entered into by K.G.B. agents searching for various religious publications. The K.G.B. confiscated 40 Bibles.
Mr Rozkalns was charged with 'anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda' and now faces a sentence of seven years deprivation of freedom plus five years internal exile.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled condemns the religious and human rights persecution within the Soviet Union.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Shipton and Mr Steedman.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Self-Government
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in November 1978 more than sixty-two per cent of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory in a Referendum rejected the introduction of Territorial Government or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.

That until the findings of the Commonwealth Grants Commission Inquiry into Australian Capital Territory finances have been made public and there has been a Referendum of the voters of the Australian Capital Territory as to their attitude to Territorial or Local Government.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Government take no further action or legislation in respect of Territorial or Local Government in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ruddock and Mr Sinclair.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the petition of the undersigned citizens, teachers and parents working in and for the interests of the pupils in government schools and colleges throughout Australia, respectfully sheweth that:

1. We deplore the unprincipled and self-interested attacks being orchestrated by minority sects and groups against the policies and person of the Commonwealth Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Hon. Senator Susan Ryan.
2. We fully support the Federal Government's actions in reducing funds for the wealthiest private schools, and in breaking the nexus between government and non -government school costs.

3. We endorse the Federal Government's principal opposition to the provision of 'base grants' to all non-government schools, as a positive step towards fulfilling their commitment of primary obligation to Australia's government schools.

4. We call upon the Federal Government however to recognise that its failure to create an adequate general recurrent resource base for government schools through providing increased recurrent grants, will undermine its own Special Programmes and thus frustrate its own stated educational objectives of greater equity and participation.

5. We support the Federal Government's stated policy of entering into direct negotiations for joint agreements on these grants with State/Territory Governments, to ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable, the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled:
The petition from parents representing the government schools in New South Wales respectfully showeth that:
1. They call on the Federal Government to re-affirm publicly that its primary obligation is to government schools.
2. They support the Federal Government's policy decision which have reduced funding to wealthy private schools and which have broken the nexus between government and non-government school costs.
3. They endorse the Federal Government's opposition to the provision of a 'base grant' to all non-government schools.
4. They ask that the Federal Government create a general recurrent resource base which is adequate for government schools through the provision of increased recurrent funding.

5. They call upon the Federal Government to negotiate agreements with State/ Territory Governments which will ensure a planned programme of improvements in government schools throughout the coming decade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aircraft Noise at Launceston, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
Whereas the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation has sat in Launceston, Tasmania, and taken evidence on the problem of aircraft noise over that city, and
Whereas that evidence has established that a prima facie case does exist on the matter of encroaching aircraft noise on the lives of people living under the existing takeoff flight paths;
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled;
Request the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation to bring down an interim report on the matter of aircraft noise at Launceston, Tasmania as a matter of urgency, as:

(a) The situation is becoming worse and, with the expected introduction of a Boeing 727 on the night freight services, the position will become intolerable for those living under the northerly takeoff flight path.
(b) There will be more jet aircraft flights at night than experienced in the day.
(c) That the present measures planned by the Department of Aviation to alleviate the noise are totally inadequate and fail to recognise the basic causes of the problem.

(d) The increasing noise problem affects the well being of the patients in five major hospitals, the aged in five aged home complexes and children in fourteen major schools and colleges, all under the mandatory flight path as laid down by the Department of Aviation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Airport at Scheyville, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:
1. that an airport in the north-west region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.

2. note that such a proposal will result in the destruction of the historic village of Pittown, Longneck Wildlife Reserve, significant Aboriginal relics and the historic Scheyville Camp and will irreversibly alter the character of the five Macquarie towns.
3. consider the resulting intolerable pollution of the Hawkesbury River.
4. note that approximately 2000 properties will be resumed, displacing over 5000 residents.

5. consider the detrimental effects of noise, air and vehicular pollution on many thousands of residents in the surrounding districts of Hawkesbury, Baulkham Hills and Hornsby Shires and Blacktown and Penrith cities.
6. give immediate consideration to finding a more suitable alternative site.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We have become the innocent victims of your Government's Medicare scheme.
We are forced to pay 1% of our wages only to receive less per capita benefits than the people of other states.

Without canvassing the rights or wrongs of the dispute between the Federal Government and the State of Queensland the fact is that because of it over one million Queenslanders, who contribute to health funds, are being blatantly discriminated against compared with people in the rest of Australia.
Because of the dispute over the introduction of Medicare, Queensland public hospital bed charges are $120 per day compared with $80.00 per day in the other states. This is grossly unfair.
As it was the Federal Government which decided to introduce Medicare, we believe it is their responsibility to take action allowing health funds' rates in Queensland to be kept at reasonable levels.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives assembled, should
Use its influence with Government so as to avoid the discrimination (of $40 per day) against insured Queenslanders
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows-

That the reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance be not deleted or removed. An alternative form of allegiance is presently available to those persons who may object to taking the form of oath containing the reference to God.
That deletion of the reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance will deny to persons who desire to make such an oath in the presence of God, the opportunity of exercising that right.

That Australia is recognized as a Christian Nation and as such, it is paramount that a continuing reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance be maintained so that our New Australian Citizens will be aware that Australia professes a Christian Way of Life.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should ensure that the reference to God in the Oath of Allegiance as it is presently worded is not removed or deleted.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of certain electors of Australia, Division of Dawson, shows-
that Australia is basically a Christian nation-as shown by figures from the last census.
that the Queen of Australia is recognised as head of Australia's Parliamentary System.

that no mandate has been sought from or given by the Australian people to alter our Oath of Allegiance, the proposal to amend the Citizenship Act not being publicised prior to the last Federal election.
that removal of references to God and the Queen is the first small, though significant, step towards Republicanism.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government does not remove references to God and the Queen from our Oath of Allegiance and that it be allowed to remain unchanged.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to undermine civil liberties and religious freedom.
It could also be a means of undermining the traditional family structure of our nation.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should delay the Bill and ask:
That the Government set up a Joint Parliamentary Committee to examine:
(a) the implications of the U.N. Covenant for public policy, the extent of Australian commitments, responsibilities and accountability in terms of the Covenant;
(b) the full effects of the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 for public policy in giving effect to the U.N. Convention.
The Terms of Reference of the Joint Parliamentary Committee to be widely publicised and oral and written submissions sought from the interested organisations and individuals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Erindale Shopping Centre, Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth our concern over the continuing delay in the provision of shopping facilities for the residents of the Tuggeranong Valley.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. building of the recently approved shopping complex on the Erindale site at Wanniassa, comprising 14,000 square metres of retail space and 4,000 square metres of other commercial space, proceed immediately; and

2. the Minister for Territories and Local Government censure the Canberra Commercial Development Authority for its blatant empire building at the expense of the Tuggeranong community and the National Capital Development Commission for recommending a retail development contrary to that discussed with the Tuggeranong community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives of Australia in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:
That because there is much concern in the community over the ratification of the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women;
That because there is much concern over the proposed Sex Discrimination Bill based upon, and intending to implement, the aforementioned UN Convention;
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:
1. Immediately rescind the ratification of the U.N. Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
2. Completely reject and abandon the Sex Discrimination Bill currently before Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble Petition of the undersigned citizen of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the expense of paying the fare to and from place of employment be regarded as a tax deduction. It costs the petitioner $300 to $500 per year for fares. If we did not go to work-NO PAY-consequently-NO TAX-So I do not think this petition is unrealistic.
Your Petitioner therefore humbly prays that this petition will be heard and a formal reply forthcoming.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows-

That existing medical supplies and services essential for the care and treatment of multiple-handicapped children and adults be retained at Victorian hospitals at no cost to the patient or their families.

Our belief in this matter is shared by the majority of affected families who will find it extremely inconvenient to travel to other locations and an intolerable economic burden if present subsidies are removed.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will take such action as it may authorise to rectify this problem.

PETITION.TITLE: Bank Account Debit Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
We, as members of a school Parent Club object to legislation that calls for the payment of the Bank Debit Tax by a voluntary organisation working for the benefit of children in government schools.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that exemption from the payment of Bank Debit Tax will be granted to School Parents' Clubs in Government schools.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia shows their concern for the present unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium, the development of nuclear power and the proliferation of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will
1. prohibit the establishment in Australia of nuclear power plants and all other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle.
2. declare a moratorium on all mining and treatment of uranium in Australia.
3. prohibit the export of Australian uranium.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

General Revenue Grants to Local Government under Personal Income Tax Sharing entitlements have increased by 8.2% in 1983-84 over 1982-83,

Increased demands are being made on Local Government Authorities to participate in Federal Government programs, e.g. Community Employment Program,
The Labor Party made a pre-election commitment to allocate not less than the real value of the previous year's allocation in General Revenue Grants to Local Government.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will amend the Local Government (Personal Income Tax Sharing) Act 1976, to provide a real term minimum guarantee to Local Government general revenue sharing arrangements in 1983-84, and in future years.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Braithwaite and Mr Katter.

last year, over 3,300 people died on Australian roads;
alcohol is a factor in 50% of road deaths;
alcohol advertisements do not show the perils of driving after drinking alcohol ;
alcohol advertisements are glamorous and increase their effect on teenagers, indicating drinking alcohol as the social pasttime;

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of concerned people of the Electorate of Farrer respectfully show their desire to stop the spread of Paterson's Curse.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife and Mr Lusher.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Victoria showeth our concern over the continuing taxation of Parents' Club bank accounts by way of the Bank Account Debit Tax.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:

Parent clubs being set up by Government Regulation in the State of Victoria ( Regulation XLII) be recognised by the Australian Government as education auxiliaries, in the same way as are School Councils.
The Treasurer move immediately to exempt Parent Clubs from the tax in the same way as are School Councils.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Hawker and Ms Mayer.

(1) We are shocked and disappointed at the Federal Government's decision not to upgrade the Wynyard Airport.
(b) This decision will inevitably lead to downgrading and closure of the Wynyard Airport.
