DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's inept and provocative handling of its dispute with the doctors .
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is mounting concern throughout Australia about the way in which the Hawke Government and the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) have mishandled the implemention of Medicare. It is a concern that is fully justified, because after just eight weeks of Medicare the health care industry is in a serious mess. When it comes to the bottom line, the thing with which we are all most concerned is our own health and our own well-being and, more particularly, that of our families and our friends. Yet the confrontationist attitudes of this Government, and this Minister in particular, have brought health care to a state where doctors are withdrawing their labour. I stress that it is the actions of this Government which have brought Australia to a health care crisis. The current dispute with medical practitioners puts the lie to the Hawke Government's incessant talk about its conciliatory approach to industrial relations. This Government will go down in history as the one government which provoked a doctors' strike, the first in the history of this country. The current situation reflects an extraordinary level of ineptitude. It reflects, indeed, the obsessive pursuit of a progressive nationalisation of both a profession and an industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to look closely at why the medical profession does not trust the Minister for Health, does not trust the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and does not trust the Australian Labor Party Government. Would any group, any association, meekly accept the fait accompli which the Minister for Health has thrust on to doctors? Does any Australian approve of the way in which this Minister is riding roughshod over the rights of doctors?

TALK.START.PARA: —Would any union?

—When the nature of the Minister's actions is seen for what it is, the answer clearly is no. That message is unquestionably getting through in every State of the Commonwealth of Australia. The level of correspondence which I and, I am certain, all honourable members on this side of the House have received, and no doubt those on the Government side have received is absolutely unprecedented. It is not just from doctors; it is from people inside and out of the health care industry who are outraged at the actions of the Minister. The public sees through the public relations smokescreen which the Government has laid down. After the millions that have been spent in trying to explain Medicare , and with the confusion that still abounds in the community, it is no wonder that I thought it fairly apt when I remarked somewhere that the most accurate advertisement that has been produced by this Government was that Medicare advertisement that ended up with the taxpayer holding the baby. Don't they know it now? The public sees through every element of this smokescreen that has been put down. But worse than that, it sees through the Minister's appeals to prejudice and his campaign of character vilification, and it is just not working . No matter how much the Government huffs and puffs about money and greed, people will not be fooled. They realise what is going on. They realise that there are fundamental principles at risk and they can see for themselves that the conditions that the Hawke Government imposes on doctors are totally unacceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that no Australian would accept the one-sided contracts which the current Minister for Health says that doctors must accept. As my honourable friend the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) interjected some moments ago, no trade union would accept the extraordinary provisions of section 17 of the Health Legislation Amendment Act. This is not a conclusion reached only by the Opposition. It is the view taken by leading authorities on industrial relations and industrial law. It would have been interesting for honourable members opposite, particularly the Prime Minister, to see Nationwide last night. We recall that it is one of his favourite programs. If he did not, let me explain very briefly what an expert on industrial law at the University of Melbourne, Mr Richard Tracey, had to say about Labor's dispute with doctors. On section 17 Mr Tracey had this to say:
There is no way that a union in this country would accept that sort of dictation to terms and conditions of employment.
He went on to support what doctors and the Opposition have been claiming for months when he said:
But it certainly would allow them to totally regulate the employment of doctors in hospitals as to all aspects of their employment.
Let me read again what this expert in industrial law said. Honourable members opposite challenge whether a trade union would be incited by section 17. Mr Tracey said:
It certainly would allow them--
that is the Government-
to totally regulate the employment of doctors in hospitals as to all aspects of their employment.

Of course, that is a fundamental and extremely important point because it goes to the nub of the matter. If this were simply a dispute about money and about the levels of fees for diagnosticians or surgeons, there is no doubt that with good will matters could be solved. But that will not happen because that is not what the dispute is about. The Minister for Health has deliberately attempted to orchestrate the misconception that it is about money. The reality is that it is not just about money, and he knows it. As Mr Tracey said last night, it is much more than that. The fact is that this Government is deeply committed to the nationalisation of the whole health care industry, and nothing less. No one will be fooled by the talk about greed and money being the obstruction. It is the old fashioned, interesting motive. The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) referred to an academic. As an aside I say that it is interesting to note that the two most disastrous members of the Hawke Ministry, of which there are a considerable number, are both academics-our lofty Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) and our lofty Minister for Health.

Behind it all is the scheme for the nationalisation of the health industry. One need go back only to the days of the old socialists, as this academic would know , to know that what is essential for the nationalisation of industry is the control and direction of labour and the control and direction of those within the given industry. That is what he is about-not the smokescreen as to money. That is why the Minister clings to the draconian powers which he wrote for himself in section 17 and the amendments which he is going along with now but which he would not go along with when we moved them in September of last year. It does not make any difference. There can be no secret about this Minister's intentions, nor about the Government's intentions. In fact, the Minister is on the record as to his strategy, and honourable members will have noted that this afternoon he did not deny his statement to the Doctors Reform Society when I asked him about it. Let me now read to the House why he could not deny it and what he actually said to the Doctors Reform Society. We have a copy of that speech which was delivered in August last year. The quotation is on page 15. For once, the Minister was brutally frank. Let me quote the paragraph leading to the essential part of this speech of the Minister for Health, the leading proponent of the socialisation of medicine. He said:
However, one area of particular concern to the Government in the public hospital sphere is the right to private practice of sessional medical staff, particularly in the diagnostic services area.
We believe, and I know you would concur-
he was talking to the Doctors Reform Society-
that the present system is far too open to kickbacks and to games with referral processes.
He went on to say and this is the nub of it:

It was agreed at the July Health Ministers Conference that attention to these problems should be initially directed to the area of diagnostic services, with the intention to move more broadly in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you strangle them one at a time.

—That is right. Let no one be in any doubt as to what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has said. Let no one be in any doubt as to what 'move more broadly' means. This Government is about the subjugation of the medical profession. That is what it is all about. The strategy is one of socialisation step by step, group by group; initially with the diagnostic services with the intention of moving more broadly in due course, as the Minister said. This explains why the Government is so desperate to get the whip hand through section 17, the guts of which still remains. The powers which it conveys to the Minister will be turned against every sector of the profession in due course. We have not seen anything like section 17 in the history of industrial relations since the Federation of this nation.
—What about the IRB you set up?

—I am glad the honourable member raised the Industrial Relations Bureau because I proposed that it be broken up. In due course it was, and properly so. Why does the honourable member not raise something that is relevant ? From the start, the way in which this Government has approached the issue of health care has been absolutely lamentable. From day one, the current Minister's attitude has been that the Government would start Medicare on 1 February regardless, and that the Government would work out the problems afterwards. To say 'We are starting on 1 February and we do not give a damn about the problems of the practitioners within the health care system' is no way to handle the health care of the nation, no way to handle the health care of individuals and no way to run a government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition pointed out the serious problems of section 17 when the Medicare legislation was going through the Parliament. We attempted back in September to amend the legislation to remove the excesses that we saw in it then. Yet the Minister, in his headlong pursuit of this grand strategy and the 1 February target date, rejected those constructive changes. Only today has he gone part of the way by picking up one element of an amendment. He has plunged ahead, to put it bluntly, like a man obsessed. In doing so, he has plunged this Government into a quagmire into which, unquestionably, it sinks deeper every day. This Minister has locked the Hawke Government into a confrontation which should never have happened. He has been provocative throughout. He has offered no realistic alternative. He has offered no real compromise because there cannot be compromise when it comes to Labor's socialist objective. That is the reality of it all and that is where the trap comes in.

Australians do not want socialist experiments. They do not want to see their family doctor as the punching bag for this Minister's Brave New World. Australians are concerned about health care. They want a health service which is efficient and unobtrusive and which preserves the cornerstone of medicine in Australia-the patient-doctor relationship. They do not want the Minister or his agents intervening in that. They do not want the confrontation they are seeing today and they do not want the lengthening queues and higher costs which this scheme brings. If the Government had taken time to consider the basic things which the public requires in health care, it would not have gone down the dead- end that it has to date. In desperation, the current Minister has seized upon the Australian Democrats' amendment to section 17 proposed in the Senate. He said that the ball is now back in the doctors' court. But the debate has moved on since such changes were first proposed last September. The damage has already been done, as was so well put by the shadow Minister for Health, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), today.

The debate has moved on since such changes were first proposed. This Minister has created a climate of well-founded distrust about his socialist intentions. A large body of opinion firmly believes that he will still use an amended section 17 to circumvent the civil conscription provisions contained in section 51 of the Constitution. The fact is that the amendment he is now supporting does not fully meet the situation today. The Opposition believes that the Government must show good faith, however belatedly, by acting now to suspend the notorious section 17 entirely until it has received the findings of the Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals. In that less confrontationist climate the Government can at least sit down with the Australian Medical Association and talk about a fair solution to the impasse; a solution which recognises the fundamental rights of any profession to negotiate a true two-way contract; a solution which lets doctors get on with their work free of concern about the intervention of the Hawke Government and which allows the public to have the health care it deserves.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing that can be said is that all that was missing from that tirade was an advertisement at the end appealing to pathologists, radiologists and other highly paid medical specialists to contribute to the Liberal Party of Australia. This Opposition has become simply the defender of a few odd elite groups. I have sat in this Parliament for eight years and I have never heard any member of the present Opposition on any occasion defend one workers' strike. Time and again, whatever the rights, in the eight years I have sat in this Parliament members of the Opposition have never supported the rights of working people to strike. Yet on the one occasion when one of the most powerful, elite groups in this society decides to use its power in this way, members of the Opposition are the first people to defend that elite group's right to bring the hospitals of this country to a stop and to threaten those within those hospitals. Indeed, they even have the hide to elevate this elite group into a trade union.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) said was simply irrelevant because a trade union is a banding together of employees in relation to an employer. We are talking about private specialists coming into hospitals and making use of those facilities. Most of them are not the employees of the hospital; they make private negotiations with the hospital. These people have been elevated by the Leader of the Opposition into a group of trade unionists; the only group of trade unionists whose right to strike these people have ever been prepared to defend.

I think it is worth simply considering in relation to this issue the Liberal Party's handling of health policy over seven years of Fraser Government which was so inept that it introduced five different and contradictory health schemes in just seven years. Of course, when it finally settled on a scheme it was a scheme which gave maximum support to its old allies, the private health funds and the medical profession. It did not matter about the public. Two million Australians were not able to find the $14 a week and more for just basic health cover, and they were not included in those rigidly defined disadvantaged categories. It did not matter that these people lived in fear of illness and accident which could land them in hospital as long as those groups, the private health funds and the private medical profession, were satisfied. Of course the important thing to remember is that those two million people who were left out are not the people who write to newspapers. They are not the people who are able to agitate and bring pressure to bear in the way that the Australian Medical Association can bring pressure to bear. The rights of those two million people were brutally attacked by the provocative actions of the previous Government. However, when the AMA is marginally affected by making demands about public accountability for the $2,000m which the taxpayers pay to the system for their benefits members of the AMA claim that that is an extraordinarily provocative action. They are able to arouse much more opposition than the two million who suffered under the actions of the previous Government.

It does not surprise me that the Liberal Party, through the Leader of the Opposition, should come to the support of the AMA. Australians have acknowledged their endorsement of the Labor governments both federally and in the four States . Let me say that the policies we are pursuing in relation to the medical profession are not policies we are pursuing alone; we are actively and willingly supported by all the Labor States. This Opposition is simply a conservative rump which increasingly represents only a small minority of Australian society. We have had success in working with most of the other groups in this society, such as trade unions and business and industry, to create a real economic recovery of which Medicare is one element.

There are, of course, a few groups like the AMA which are still clinging to the wreckage on the other side and which, unlike business and other groups in the community, have not recognised the economic realities of Australia in the 1980s. The AMA has been for decades an isolated cartel excluded from almost all market forces by the insurance system and isolated against economic need in recession, again because of this insurance system. This latter point is especially true when this Government's Medicare program provides universal cover which of course underpins the doctors' income even in difficult times.

In making these comments about the professionals and their privileges, I do not make them from a narrow, ideological viewpoint. Commentators as diverse as Justice Michael Kirby, the Chairman of the Law Reform Commission, and Milton Friedman, of conservative economic fame and probably one of the 'dry' idols of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), have been critical of the protected, isolated position of the profession. Justice Kirby, in his recent Wilkinson Oration, observed:

There is no doubt that the Australian community has a growing perception of professional people as selfish self seekers, earning high levels of income in times of economic recession, using the special dependence of the community upon their skill as an immoral bargaining weapon in the pursuit of greater wealth, yet free from much public accountability.

I believe that Justice Kirby is right in his comment about Australian attitudes to the professions. I believe that this shows how divorced the Liberal Party of Australia has become from the mainstream of Australian thought that it would be going to the barriers to support the AMA and its irresponsible industrial action over this issue.

What this dispute is all about is the Government trying to exert some reasonable and marginal controls over the payment of Medicare benefits. I would have thought that even the Liberal Party would accept that, where $2,000m is being paid out in benefits, the Government has some responsibility to make sure it is spent wisely and properly. I will quote again from Justice Kirby's recent speech. He said:
When Parliament votes the public's money it is absolutely basic that it has the right to assert its interpretation of the people's will.
He went on to say:

The lawyers reap the benefit of legal aid. The doctors and in part the dentists take advantage of Medicare, but it is a fundamental principle of our system of government that public funds come attached with public strings.

Despite the Opposition, and despite the opposition out there from a privileged and elite profession, we are determined that there should be some strings in relation to the public funding of the system. What are these public strings we are seeking to attach to the payment of Medicare benefits for diagnostic service in public hospitals? What is this debate all about? When one forgets these elevated fantastical notions in which one transforms the AMA into a trade union and then tries to attach to it all of the rights of employees battling against employers, what is the argument really about? First of all, I can tell honourable members that our proposals are mild indeed when compared with the recommendations of the previous Government's own report from the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. It recommended:
. . . steps be taken to phase out over a period of years the right of private practice for full time salaried specialists.
It also recommended:

There be an urgent review by each of the employment authorities of rights to private practice in hospitals with a view to limiting its scope, consistent with the underlying intent of the contract between an individual patient and doctor.

What did the previous Government do about those strong recommendations from a very conservative report? It must have been a matter of grave concern for Jamison to make such sweeping recommendations. The Fraser Government, of course, ignored them. It always pretended to be a tough government, but every time it really was faced with tough issues it ran away from them, turned away from them, as does the Opposition now on a whole range of issues. This Government has been prepared to take up some of those tough issues, and this is one of them.

As I have outlined earlier, the Liberals took no action because it was their own constituency, the highly paid medical specialists, who were affected by these clear recommendations in a conservative report. Who were the beneficiaries of this exploitation of the public hospital system? The answer is obvious. Not only did the Liberal Government ignore Jamison, it ignored what members of its own Party were saying about some of the excessively generous private practice rights that exist in some areas of the public hospital system. I will now read to honourable members what Mr Greiner, the thankfully still Opposition leader in New South Wales for another four years, said when he was a member of the Public Accounts Committee of the New South Wales Parliament. He said:

The medical profession has an obligation to ensure that the public funds it accepts, and more importantly commits, are utilised to maximum effect and are properly accounted. Historically, the profession has not adequately recognised this obligation.
Mr Greiner went on, when referring to private practice Scheme C in the New South Wales public hospital system:
With respect to Scheme C, it is fair to say that a considerable weight of opinion believes it to be excessively generous. This opinion is shared by many staff specialists working under other schemes.

Even the profession itself realises that there is exploitation, especially in the area of diagnostic services. The Australian Association of Surgeons, which now leaps to the barricades to defend so-called professional freedom, said in its submission to the Jamison inquiry:

There are cases of patients tested to the point of exhaustion for reasons entirely unknown to their principal medical attendant. There is little doubt that many of these diagnostic testing procedures represent an unwarranted invasion of privacy inflicted on the patient and many of them cause unnecessary suffering and hardship. Their cost to the community is almost inestimable.
That was not a statement of the Doctors Reform Society, it was a statement of the highly conservative Surgeons Association, when talking about radiologists and pathologists.

Unlike the previous Government which ran away from these important issues, this Government gave them careful consideration in the planning of its Medicare program. We do not want to do away with private practice rights in public hospitals because we believe that they are an essential attraction that must be maintained if we are to retain the highest quality medical staff in the public hospital system. I point out that it is not on the whole the salaried doctors who are on strike-though we have some opposition here in Canberra-it is primarily the visiting doctors coming in from outside who simply cream off the cake who have been taking most of this irresponsible action. These people would rather strike than make a submission to a proper inquiry because they know that the weight of logic is on the Government's side. They would rather use their industrial muscle than rationally argue their case before an independent inquiry .

The Opposition argues that the Federal Government has no right to intrude on a contract freely negotiated between hospitals and doctors. But this is nonsense. After all, who is it who pays Medicare benefits for private practice work in public hospitals? It is, of course, the Commonwealth Government through the taxpayer funded Medicare program. The fact of the matter is that hospitals have no direct interest in limiting private practice rights because they do not have to foot the bill for them. Of course, now that we have four State Labor Governments they have taken a realistic and responsible attitude to this matter and we have all worked closely together in developing the reasonable limitations that the section 17 guidelines impose on these private practice rights. But ultimately the final responsiblity rests with the Commonwealth Government because, as I stated previously in this speech, it is our responsibility to ensure that the $2,000m in Medicare benefits are properly and wisely spent.

Members of the Opposition have rambled on and now even accuse the Government of nationalising the public hospital system. I remind them that the doctors who work in those hospitals are taxpayer trained and use taxpayer funded facilities and therefore should accept their public accountability. It would be absolutely contrary to the interests of any government, especially a Labor Government, to introduce any guidelines under section 17 that were so unreasonable as to cause an exodus of doctors from the public hospital system. The Government and I have gone out of our way to be responsible and considerate towards the reasonable individual objections put forward by the AMA. For instance, issues such as income restraint and national facility charges have been referred to the joint Government and AMA Penington Committee of Inquiry into the Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals which the Government established to consider the broader questions of private practice rights.

Today the Government has gone even further by guaranteeing immediate appeal rights to the Federal Parliament, the highest authority in the land, by introducing a Bill which will permit guidelines under section 17 of the Health Legislation Amendment Act to be disallowed by either House of the Parliament if either House feels them to be unreasonable. Moreover the Commonwealth Government is limited because it could not put into practice any of those guidelines without the co-operation and support of at least most of the States.

It is the Government's sincere hope that this decision today should settle the current industrial dispute before it escalates to the point where patients' well -being is endangered. As Senator Haines observed when she recently put forward her constructive proposal for parliamentary scrutiny, if the AMA refuses to accept this proposal to settle the dispute it 'certainly makes a mockery of the Opposition's assertion that the row would not have occurred if the Government had agreed to amendments last year'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there are two things which emerge from this debate, they are these: Firstly, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has been digging his own grave in his portfolio by his attitude to the medical profession . It is not just a question of the issues in this matter but whether there can be any confidence at all between the Minister and the profession on which he must rely to introduce his Medicare program. If I were a member of this profession, if the principal body that I belonged to for professional and other reasons had been called an isolated cartel, if I had been referred to as a member of an elite profession, supremely privileged and cut off from reality, if I had been referred to as the equivalent of the Builders Labourers Federation in the way I went about my business, if indeed in the previous few years I had been a visiting medical officer in a public hospital, if I were one of the almost half of such doctors who still give voluntary service in treating pensioners and disadvantaged patients, if I were a surgeon who had trained for 13 years before getting a fellowship and had a professional life which could be shortened by failing eyesight or some other physical disability, if every day I were running risks in deciding on people's lives, if I were giving service in a painstaking way and if I had heard this debate and this Minister referring to me, by extension, in the terms that he has used, I would have no confidence in anything he said. I would be outraged at the way he had attacked my profession. I would believe nothing he said. I would be utterly determined to press for what I regarded as constitutional rights. That is the first thing that emerges from this debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing that emerges from this debate relates to the questions that will be asked by patients and their relatives. They will ask: 'Why on earth is the Minister doing it? Why on earth is he elevating this matter of section 17, which is of supreme importance to the doctors who believe that he is using it to overcome the civil conscription provisions of the Constitution, and which is of no real importance to him in his whole Medicare architecture, to the point where he has put his own ministerial position in jeopardy?' I simply cannot understand why this matter of the diagnosticians' fees in public hospitals should be elevated to the point where it can threaten the whole architecture which the Minister, from his side of politics, has regarded as the greatest social reform of the Hawke Government.

Basically what has been happening is that the Minister has said that his concern is with the fees charged and the level of income earned by diagnostic specialists in public hospitals within the States. He put forward a lot of arguments to show that some of those contracts gave unusually and unnecessarily high levels of income to those specialists. That may well be so. He quoted from Mr Greiner in support of this. I have absolutely no reason to doubt what Mr Greiner has said. Indeed, I acknowledge what has been said in the report of the Jamison Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals. It has transpired in the course of the debate over the last few months that these diagnostic specialists are in fact charging the schedule fee or less to their patients under their existing contracts; that they are being charged facilities charges by hospitals for the use of public facilities as indeed they should be because these are provided by taxpayers. Hospitals are already doing that.

It has emerged that Dr Cornwall, the Minister of Health in South Australia, said that he was perfectly satisfied with the arrangements he had made with the AMA in that State. Dr Blewett then asked him to implement price control by State regulation on the doctors who were already complying with contracts which were within the schedule fee or below. It also emerged that the Victorian Minister of Health, Mr Roper, had come to a similar conclusion with his AMA and that he was not concerned with proceeding with section 17. However, to help his Federal colleague off the hook, he also introduced price control regulation. The New South Wales Government, with a new health Minister, who is a little more personable than the previous one, in the midst of a State election did not go ahead with price control regulation. He too indicated that diagnostic specialists in New South Wales were indeed charging no more than the schedule fee and in many cases were charging less and that the radiologists were putting back 60 per cent of their earnings into facilities charges.

Those contracts may still not be all right. I am quite prepared to acknowledge that. They may still be giving an unfair advantage to certain diagnostic groups. But, heaven forbid, there are ways and means of overcoming that without elevating this dispute to the level of a constitutional challenge. If the doctors genuinely and sincerely believe, and given the remarks that this Minister has made over a very long time, I am not surprised that they did not believe this, that section 17 is a way of getting around the restrictions on the conscription of doctors prohibited under section 51 of the Constitution and if they regard it as being an absolutely untenable Federal control over their, in effect, small businesses and private independent practices, why should not the Minister remove these offending sections and await the outcome of the Penington inquiry, have discussions on ways of containing the incomes of those diagnostic specialists in the State hospital systems, sit down in a reasonable way to do this and the whole problem will stop immediately? All this strike action will stop immediately if he agrees to do that. That is what the Opposition has proposed today. That was the content of the private member's Bill which I put forward earlier but which the Government refused to consider in the House.

Let me make one thing perfectly clear. The Minister began his speech by stating something that was absolutely incorrect. If he deals with the AMA in this way I can understand why it would have some concern about dealing with him further. He said that the Opposition had defended the doctors' right to strike. On no occasion have I publicly done so. On no occasion have we in this House done so. I think it is appalling that professional people looking after patients in hospitals are on strike. I would be concerned if they were asked to sign contracts which they regarded as unconscionable. It would be a different matter if as a result of refusing to sign those contracts they were denied access to the hospitals. In that case the responsiblity for the whole action would be with the hospitals, the employing authorities, and with the Minister. The Opposition has not defended the right of these professional people to strike. I put that on the record and deny as absolutely incorrect something which the Minister has said.

Equally we have not equated doctors with trade unionists. We have merely pointed out that the ways of dealing with human beings, ways which we believe are necessary in the industrial relations field and which we support, are those of reasonable conciliation, arbitration, fair hearing and abiding by the results . These rules are not one sided contracts that can be altered by one side. These rules apply to trade unionists. We do not see why the same civil liberties should not apply to professional people. That does not mean to say that we have equated doctors with trade unionists. Doctors are in a totally different situation. They are professional, independent people for the most part. In fact they are running something like a small business.

The main concern the Opposition has is for the patients. The patients in the hospitals who are waiting to have elective surgery done and are being held up, and their families who are desperately concerned about their health, ask this Minister why on earth he wants section 17 of the Health Legislation Amendment Act so badly. Is it a critical part of the architecture of his great social reform so called? Is it essential to drive the doctors to distraction over a concern about their constitutional position and the 1946 amendment to the Constitution? Why on earth is the Minister doing it? Section 17 is absolutely inessential for the architecture of Medicare. Medicare can go on perfectly happily without it. Ways and means can be found, sitting down with the doctors after the Penington report and after the removal of these clauses, to deal with these relatively minor matters of the diagnosticians in the public hospitals. The Opposition asks the Minister to return to sanity in this matter and we ask for it on behalf of the patients.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not surprising that the Opposition seems to be pre-occupied with the payment of doctors' fees and is unable to accept the decision that the people of Australia made in March last year. The concentration of honourable members opposite on this issue is very disturbing. It would seem to me that many issues in the health care area are much more important and perhaps deserve a great deal more consideration. There are the issues of preventive medicine, industrial health, community health, health education and medical research. All of these matters are important and should require our attention. It is a shame that we are continually confronted with disruption and confusion by honourable members opposite. I have heard Opposition members speaking on this issue. We are not talking about the majority of doctors. We are talking about those diagnostic doctors who have a private practice in a public hospital. They represent a very small percentage of doctors-much less than one per cent of all doctors.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Medical Association which purports to represent doctors in this country represents perhaps 60 per cent of doctors. When one qualifies in medicine in this country one automatically becomes a member of the AMA free of charge. It extends that privilege immediately to those who have qualified. In fact there are very substantial privileges for those who have just qualified. When one talks about practising doctors and doctors in the work force the number is perhaps distorted.

I believe the issue is twofold. The first and most important is that it is not a new requirement that the States and the Government should be concerned about what goes on in public hospitals and about the rights of private practice in public hospitals. It needs to be remembered that the taxpayers educate the doctors. The taxpayers build the hospitals, they equip the hospitals, they staff the hospitals and they pay for the administration in those hospitals. It seems very unreasonable that the Government should not have any control over what happens within those hospitals, indeed that the taxpayers, through the Government, should not have any control over what happens in those hospitals. We in Western Australia are perhaps a little more enlightened. A number of years ago debate was carried out on this argument, We have agreements in the public hospitals that are substantially within the guidelines laid down.

It seems amazing that the schedule fee should be controversial. It is an arbitrated fee independently agreed on by the medical benefits fees inquiry. I find it very hard to understand why we have so much difficulty with charging the schedule fee in a public hospital. I will draw an analogy. Is the Opposition suggesting that school teachers using public facilities in government schools should be able to carry out classes during school hours in classrooms that are empty, be paid, and that the Government not have any say in what happens in those schools? I think that is exactly what we are talking about here. We are talking about publicly funded facilities and the rights of the Government to have some sort of control over what happens in those facilities.

The second issue-it is one for which I have had some sympathy with the doctors- is with regard to agreements under which doctors believed there was no consultative or appeal mechanisms. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) has been involved in consultation since August. In response to the concerns of the AMA and other doctors a number of discussions and concessions have been made available. I have been involved in one or two of those discussions betweeen the Minister and the AMA in my State. The Penington Committee of Inquiry into Rights of Private Practice in Public Hospitals was set up to provide for appropriate appeals and consultative mechanisms. Subsequently the Government undertook that during the Penington inquiry no change of any sort would occur within the guidelines. The Government also accepted the Committee's recommendation relating to appeal and review procedures. The Government said that it would abide by the Penington Committee's recommendations.

Today the Minister has made a further concession with regard to parliamentary scrutiny of his power to make guidelines. Clearly the ball is back in the court of the doctors and the AMA. We have to wait to see what the AMA will do. Will it act on behalf of a very small number of practitioners, a very elite and privileged group? Will it be as obdurate as it has been in the past or will it be responsive? Can the AMA be trusted? I receive monthly reports from the Western Australian branch of the Australian Medical Association. On the front page of the Branch News for March 1984 it is stated:
The increase in demand for beds in teaching hospitals is pushing staff and resources to the limit.

This is on the front page of the AMA Branch News for doctors throughout Western Australia. I thought that this was a source of concern. Perhaps patients are suffering as a consequence. I made inquiries of the medical superintendents and the administrators at all of these major hospitals. What did I find? I found that this assertion was mendacious in the extreme. In fact there is no significant increase in the number of patients in public hospitals. There is no change to the number of patients. The AMA is just continuing its attacks on Medicare which are ideologically based rather than being made for any practical reason. For the vast majority of practitioners-I am talking about practitioners who are working in general practice-the Medicare arrangements mean no change. For the vast majority of Australians they mean no change except that two million Australians who were not covered for health care are now covered. That is something to which I find it very difficult to take exception. I suppose it is an indication of the Opposition's stance on this issue.

This debate on Medicare has been a very tortuous one. Last August the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar) said that Medicare-perhaps this is an indication of the level of debate from the Opposition-would bring about an influx of free-loading sick people from overseas. That is the standard of debate that we have had. Today the Opposition has talked about the doctor-patient relationship. What on earth the private practice arrangement within public hospitals has to do with doctor-patient relationship I do not know. Doctors in diagnostic positions hardly ever see the patients with whom they are dealing. Today we had the old story about one's choice of a doctor and how that should be one's inalienable right. That is maintained within the Medicare agreement. The Opposition talked about how people should be able to have the specialist of their choice. I put it to honourable members that it is not possible that the vast majority of the public is in any position to indicate or to make a correct decision as to who is a good specialist and what sorts of services he provides. Again we have had a large degree of misleading information.

What this issue comes down to is simply this: The Government provides facilities, equipment, staff and administration in public hospitals. The Government pays out about $2 billion a year for the provision of those services in public hospitals. It is fair and reasonable that the Government should have a say in how that money is spent and what goes on in its public facilities.

There is a need for a change of direction of the health debate in this country away from how doctors are paid. I know of very few doctors who are struggling. There is a need to turn towards those issues on which I believe we should concentrate, such as preventive medicine, industrial health, community health, research and health education. There is a need for the public to be aware of the fact that the Government substantially funds public facilities in which private practice rights are given. The Government should always be in control and have a say in what happens in those public facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the House of Representatives, having considered message No. 181 of the Senate relating to the proposed appointment of a joint select committee to inquire into and report on certain matters relating to tapes and transcripts delivered by the Age newspaper to the Attorney-General on 1 February 1984, does not concur with the resolution of the Senate; and
(2) that a message be sent to the Senate acquainting it of this resolution.

This resolution was born in the Senate on the concept that the Senate felt that it would be able to do a service for the people of Australia by having a joint committee of inquiry to inquire into some type of evidence that appears to have been obtained from the Age newspaper. The Age newspaper was able to furnish a series of tapes-I think four in number-and transcripts, which had no bearing on the tapes, relating to telephone conversations which allegedly took place between certain people. At the outset, it appears very clear that the Senate may establish such a committee. The Government understands that that may well happen . But from the Government's point of view it is beyond belief to think that, because a newspaper produces some form of tape or transcript, the national Parliament then establishes a committee which undertakes what is virtually a trial of the alleged behaviour of a member of the judiciary.

Prior to the recent parliamentary break this House was able to answer any questions put forward by the Opposition at the time on a number of matters, all of which questions related quite significantly to a judge of the High Court of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you did not really answer, did you?
—We did answer the questions, despite the objection.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members should contain themselves. What is very significant and what ought to be listened to is that what the Opposition is about apparently happened-if it did happen-in 1979.
—Ah! But you concede that it may have happened?

—No, I am asking the question: Why is it that after five years we suddenly unearth a suggestion that something has happened which entitles this Parliament to appoint a committee of inquiry into the veracity of matters arising from a newspaper which has produced something which appears to be a tape . The question that the Australian public wants answered is: By what senior authority do honourable members opposite, members of parliament, place themselves above the law?
—You talked to us about the smuggling of birds.
—I notice that the honourable member chases other ones, so what is the problem?
—I do not know about that. You talked about smuggling. You did not tell us anything about the facts of this matter.

—As the honourable member is so interested in birds, as he obviously is, I say to him that the smuggling case applied to a police officer who was prosecuted by the then Attorney-General, who failed in the prosecution. The then Attorney-General then lodged an ex officio indictment against the man after nine months delay because the man had something to say about other matters that did not relate to birds. He happened to be attending the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. During the administration of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), that man suggested-and I am pleased to see that one of the honourable members concerned is present opposite-that the Customs officers and the Narcotics Bureau were not functioning properly and were unable to prevent the introduction into Australia of drugs such as heroin.

SPEECH.PARA: Because he gave evidence in camera to the Williams Royal Commission the then Government persecuted and prosecuted him. The Leader of the Opposition was silly enough to talk about birds. The man I speak of was acquitted. Why the Opposition wants to know about the Age tapes relates to the same rule. No one must cross the establishment opposite. The Opposition wants to have a joint committee by which it will place itself above the law to assess whether the judge is fit and proper to remain on the Bench. What are the special characteristics of members of the Opposition? Why are they above the law?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am simply a member of the Parliament and the Constitution requires the Parliament to examine the issue.

—No. The issue is very clear. The Constitution requires the Parliament to do certain things when there is clear evidence of illegality or criminal conduct, but not on the basis of the doubtful, hearsay proposition that we have here. We have the four tapes of the Age. We will wait patiently for six tapes from some other newspaper which might well relate to an alleged conversation that took place between the Leader of the Opposition and somebody else in this country. Is this the standard of conduct we are now to condone? When somebody produces a magical thing called a tape are we immediately to appoint a committee of this Parliament to try that person? Is this the standard of proof we now apply? Cannot this national Parliament rely on its own laws to prosecute the question of whether there has been any illegality, to indicate clearly whether there has been any misconduct? I think that is the great worry.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue has nothing to do with the fact that the Opposition dislikes a member of the High Court. The reasons for its dislike are not related to his judgments but to the fact that he used to be a member of the Australian Labor Party. That is the measure of the Opposition's objection to the man. This is not the first time that criminal proceedings have been launched at what I would call the instigation of the philosophy which has applied in the Opposition. If one looks at the Sankey case when Ministers of a former Labor government faced conspiracy charges, one will see the same motivation to denigrate and downgrade anybody who had any affiliation with the Labor Party and who had been a member of this Parliament, whether a member of the House of Representatives or the Senate.

If we allow this sort of conduct to be tolerated, it means in political terms that the Opposition will be looking for tapes and information from all the pimps , informers and fizgigs around the place, to give it some information that somebody in the past did something wrong, because it has a tape or a complaint. If that is the standard, I say that democracy in this country is finished. No person could now enter public life and be secure from the fact that somebody might say in the Parliament: 'I have a tape. We will now have a committee and a trial. We will summon people to attend and explain their conduct. Are they guilty or innocent?'. What right have members of the Opposition to place themselves above the law of the land? They have none at all, unless there is at least some clear evidence of illegality or misconduct.

The matters that the Age newspaper was so anxious to promote, after a delay of some years, were given to the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Solicitor- General. In both cases they clearly indicated that there was no evidence of any suggestion of illegality or misconduct. Those opinions were given to the Leader of the Opposition. This matter has been the subject of a very keen debate in the Senate on the basis that members of the Senate felt that they would be able to judge for all time whether there was any merit in the tapes. Let me make it very clear that this happens to be the start of an example whereby apparently the Senate will forever have a committee that will be what is called the McCarthyist committee of the nation. The committee will always have the numbers to be able to ask people to give evidence before it on any matter. Where are the rights of privacy or the rights of people to defend themselves, if this is the standard of conduct?

The Government makes it very clear that it certainly will not be able, in the Senate, to stop the committee going ahead. It does not approve of it, but if the Senate wishes to establish it, that is what the Senate will do. We make the point, though, that there was never any evidence of misconduct or illegality by any person, as evidenced by the tapes submitted. That is very clear. The other point is that the manufacturing of evidence by tapes leaves a lot to be desired from the point of view of conduct. As honourable members know, this particular ' evidence' has been the subject of examination by the Joint Police Task Force and others. There is clear evidence that the tapes are certainly not what one would call original tapes. They have been edited to some extent at least, if in fact they are valid in any sense of the word.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you listened to them?

—I have not listened to them. But it would not be very hard for a couple of people, such as those of whom the honourable member knows, to manufacture tapes; not very hard at all. The motivation is the interesting thing . After a delay of five years the tapes are produced-conveniently, we will say- on the basis that they might affect a State election in New South Wales. That was the real motivation. This question now arises: Why is it that the Opposition , which has so much access to this knowledge and which was obviously able to gain some advantage from it, cannot produce the person who prepared the tape? That is the point that the Opposition should face up to. Under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act, a law of this Parliament, as honourable members know, that person is liable to years of imprisonment and a penalty of $5 ,000 or $6,000. Also, any honourable member who uses the tape is liable to the same penalty. I know the Opposition's normal sense of courage, and that might be the reason why it is not prepared to do anything about it.

SPEECH.PARA: That law of the Commonwealth purports to protect the privacy of the people of this nation. It says, in effect, that nobody is entitled to intercept a telephone conversation made by anybody. Nobody is entitled to do that, and if a person does it, he will find himself in gaol and subject to a massive penalty. Yet once that has been done, the Opposition uses this criterion: 'Give it to us and we will see whether we can use it to our benefit'. Is this the standard of what one could call 'government' by the Opposition? Will we now have a trial by the media whereby, because the Opposition is desperate to return to the government benches, it will use any method to denigrate anybody, as I say, even if it is illegal, and not bother to prosecute the people who broke the law? Do members of the Opposition expect the people of the nation to judge them in this way as being fit and proper people to be on the government benches?

It is just an aberration that in the Senate there is a splinter group of senators who feel that they always want to get into the act and be the centre of attraction, so that they will set up this committee and appear on it like the Perry Masons and hope that the television cameras focus on how brilliant they are in cross-examination. But we could say to them: 'What about the person or persons who broke the law? What about all of those police officers or others who betrayed their trust and intercepted telephone conversations?' How many committees will we have which will listen to all the other tapes that have been taken about any one of us, including all members of the Opposition? The Opposition will be the recipient of every tape that is brought forward. People may say, with regard to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard): 'Listen to what he said on 27 June 1981 when he was talking to Mr O'Reilly about how he could not do anything about the straw companies and the tax that they were evading'. Will we have a committee on the question of what he said on that occasion? Is this the standard of conduct?

TALK.START.PARA: —I made all that public. I have nothing to hide.

—The honourable member has plenty to hide. He has a stack to hide when we look at the report that he tabled. He did nothing for years. That is the point. We will let him get out of it because he is now in opposition. But if we are bedevilled by a series of tapes and leaks by people who feel something should have been done after a period of years, surely this nation demands a better standard than that. The Telecommunications (Interception) Act is certainly right when it talks about severely punishing people who have the capacity to intercept telephone conversations and then attempt to use them. People can be punished on two counts-the interceptor and the person who receives the information that was intercepted. In other words, the Age newspaper and its proprietors are liable to that penalty. But are they prepared to say: 'We do not have to disclose any information'?
—Why do you hate the Age?

—I do not hate the Age. I am trying to preserve some method of standard of conduct in this nation. It is very hard to do so with the Opposition that we have, because it is running true to form. I refer honourable members to the 1975 period and the accusations of conspiracy made against four former Ministers of the Government. It was a despicable, rotten action, sponsored by a person called Mr Sankey. The Opposition still cannot tell me-it is not game to say-who paid Mr Sankey's costs of $80,000. We see champerty, maintenance and all sorts of criminal actions which the Opposition is prepared to condone. It is very clear that we are discussing matters of major significance at this stage. A High Court judge is expected to appear before a Senate committee which will ask him: 'Did you do this or did you not?' I assume he will say: 'I did not do it'. What will the committee do then? It will probably say: 'We do not believe you'. That is about as far as we will go. But I make this point: Why can we not find the person or persons who did the interception? Why can we not find the police officer or some other person-this is evidence-who said: 'On such and such a date I heard this happening; I understand the position'. Then we might be able to say that some person exists. But in this case all we have is some tapes and some transcripts. God knows who prepared them; they certainly do not relate to the tapes because we cannot find the tapes relating to the transcripts. The nation will then see a resolution of this Parliament suggesting that we had better do something about this matter. I think it has been made very clear by a couple of senators that they have many other tapes. So where does it all end?
—Who has them?
—I do not know. The Leader of the Opposition had better ask them , because they are on his side.
—Who are the senators? You just said that a couple of senators had tapes.
—Yes, I said that I think it has been made very clear. The Leader of the Opposition should ask them.
—You just said that a couple of senators had tapes.
—Yes--
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—The Leader of the Opposition should not get so enthusiastic, because we might find a tape on him, and we would all be anxious to have a committee to look into that. If this is the standard of conduct, it just shows what we are heading into. Someone produces a tape, and, whether in the Senate or in the House of Representatives-I suggest that there is more evidence in the Senate than in the House of Representatives, apparently-we then, because it is leaked to a newspaper, have to say to the Parliament: 'We have to do something about this matter'. I put it to you quite squarely, Mr Speaker: No responsible democracy in the world would be reacting to this sort of nonsense, particularly when the period of delay is five years. Five years ago something allegedly happened. We now have to have a committee that will investigate whether a judge is a fit and proper person to remain on the High Court of Australia. It remains very clear that this judge was hounded in the past on a conspiracy action simply because he was a member of the Australian Labor Party. Because apparently that is not to be forgotten, any allegation, spurious as it may be, fabricated as it obviously could be, by tapes and transcripts, will merit a further investigation of the person. No court in Australia would deem to think that there was even a prima facie case on the submission of a tape or a document.

SPEECH.PARA: Where are the people behind this? Where is the evidence of the informant? Why cannot that person be put in the witness box and tested as to 'What were your duties?', or, better still, 'How much did you get for the information that you are now peddling?' Is that the standard of conduct that the Opposition wants in Australia? I would say that many thinking parliamentarians would agree that that is the last thing that they would want to see happening to their constituents or anyone else. If the standard of allegation now in this nation is, 'Bypass the courts; do not give any information to the police or to anyone else; just produce a tape; get a couple of actors to do it if you like, and use their voices perhaps to emulate someone else, and we will use that as a fabrication', where does one draw the line after that if every newspaper in the world publishes that and the Opposition gives it some credibility by putting forward a resolution of this type?

In fairness to the Leader of the Opposition, I suppose that he had to rely on the Senate to produce the resolution. But this Senate Committee, which will obviously be established, will, I would say, be the forerunner of many, because the precedent from here on will be, no matter to whom it relates, if it is a person in public life, a person in another parliament or a person on the Bench, every one of them will now be suspect on the basis that perhaps someone produces a tape or a transcript. They will all be carted off to this high-powered group called a Senate committee which will put itself above everyone else and dictate whether those concerned are fit and proper people to remain in their positions.

The Constitution is very clear. It would require very strong and substantial evidence, certainly tested in the normal judicial way, before any action would be taken on the joint resolution of both Houses of Parliament pursuant to section 72 of the Constitution. That is the required standard: The judicial test , with the evidence tested properly, and the question of findings by a judge or a court on that conduct. It is not this extraordinary situation of a newspaper, a media outlet, getting hold of information, paid for or otherwise. For that reason, we reject the proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not agree to this motion. The motion, moved by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen), is virtually telling the Senate to take a running jump at itself and is telling this whole Parliament to ignore its rights and, indeed, its duties under the Constitution. We support the establishment of a Joint Select Committee, which was contained within message No. 181 of the Senate, and we reject the motion moved by the Deputy Prime Minister to advise the Senate that this House does not concur in the resolution that was passed in that chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I address the substance of the matters contained in the resolution calling for a joint inquiry of this Parliament, let me just say one thing. I have just listened to 20 minutes of some of the greatest hypocrisy spoken in this Parliament, in which the Deputy Prime Minister of this country stood before the Parliament and described honourable members on this side of the House as wishing to peddle illegal material, tapes and transcripts, and to use them on any occasion to bring down anybody. There is one harsh reality of which the people of Australia are well aware. There is but one group of people in this Parliament who savaged and ruined the reputation of an Australian by dint of tapes, without any trial and without his having any opportunity to answer for himself. That clique was the Cabinet group, subsequently endorsed by the Caucus, which contained within its ranks the Deputy Prime Minister, who moved against David Combe and shattered his livelihood and his reputation. Let not the Deputy Prime Minister come into this Parliament today and tell me that he and his Party are the apotheosis of civil liberties when they have torn them asunder, without the opportunity being given to a man to be able to protect himself. I will not listen to that rubbish or let it go through, when he is prepared to crucify a man and to come in here with crocodile tears, stroking his platitudes until they purred, and saying to us that he is the only person and his is the only group concerned with civil liberties. No wonder we oppose the sort of motion that he puts up.

I do not intend to go into all of the background of the matter. I pose the question: Why did the Government not have this matter investigated from the moment it was raised? We would have been spared a month-two weeks in this Parliament and two weeks during the New South Wales election campaign-if this Government had moved expeditiously and had accepted our advice that the matter ought to be inquired into. As the Deputy Prime Minister has conceded, it is to be inquired into, anyhow. This Government has allowed this nation to suffer the penalty of having this hullabaloo going on for a month when it could have acted upon it immediately. It has duck-shoved, run away and obfuscated, and now in the end, when it could pick up a joint inquiry, the terms of which said that the Committee was not to commence its hearing until after the holding of the New South Wales election, it will not even pick that up. The Government knows the inevitability of an inquiry which will be launched in the Senate itself.

The reason the Opposition supports a joint inquiry is that the Constitution, under which all citizens and this Parliament are bound, contains in section 72( ii) the provision that both Houses of the Parliament are to address this matter. If that is what the Constitution says-and it does; both the House and the Senate -is it not preferable that if a committee is going to inquire into the matter, both Houses be represented on it, because the Constitution requires both Houses to address the matter? The Government will duck, weave and obfuscate and use its numbers to defeat this Committee, but it will not be able to use its numbers to defeat the Committee of the Senate, because the Senate, recognising the role of the Parliament, will take its path and will launch a Senate inquiry.

We were asked today why we were placing ourselves above the law. We are the only ones abiding by the law because the law provides for both Houses of the Parliament to participate in this matter. That is the harsh underlying reality so far as the law is concerned. It is not a question of politics. As I reminded honourable members, paragraph (3) of the resolution passed by the Senate nearly three weeks ago stated that the inquiry was not even to commence until after the holding of the New South Wales election. To come here today with a constant crying of crocodile tears and to tell us that we are interested only in destroying the civil liberties of distinguished Australians when but one group has done that in the last 12 months, namely, the Government, ought to be treated with the contempt I am giving it.

Now I go to the matter. The reason that the Opposition is proceeding with this course of action is that it believes both Houses ought to be dealing with the matter, a matter that is devolved by the Constitution on the whole Parliament and not on the Senate alone. If the Government will not allow the proposed joint parliamentary inquiry to go ahead, we will move in the Senate, as I have indicated, for it to proceed. Just remember that, for all the abuse that was forthcoming a moment ago, we did not rush into the Parliament and kick heads, as some pundits expected us to do. If one traces the history of this matter one will see that this Opposition has behaved responsibly throughout, right from the first moment. We asked for the matters to be put before us in a sanitised form with the names deleted to protect the innocent, and the Government refused. We called for a judicial inquiry, and the Government refused. We called for a royal commission, and the Government refused. Now we call for a joint select committee as required under the Constitution for both Houses to play their role, and the Government refuses again.

Step by step we have taken responsible actions, and the Government, which castigates the forthcoming Senate committee, has known all along that it would face that fact and has sought to shift the onus on to others. It has sought to shift the ground so that it can delay and delay in the hope that it would be able, through that delay, to escape the investigation that is required. It will not. We even moved a censure of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and of the Government and were unable to get a response. We have given the Government opportunity after opportunity and by its very obduracy it has created the sensationalism that has surrounded this matter. Now once more it has refused . It has refused to agree to the proposal for a joint select committee, a vehicle through which it can, as a government, act; and it will take the consequences of its actions.

Let us review briefly the Government's arguments for refusing to deal properly with this matter. The Government admits that misbehaviour is a matter for the Parliament, but it says that the Parliament is not at liberty to determine what the criterion for misbehaviour is. What fanciful nonsense is that! What tortuous legal logic! It is plain nonsense. The Constitution says plainly that it is for the Parliament to determine what misbehaviour is. If that is the case, the Parliament has to be at liberty to determine what the criterion is. The Government, following the opinions of Mr Temby and of the Solicitor-General, says that there are only two grounds for misbehaviour-behaviour attaching to the performance of the judge in his judicial office and misbehaviour in the sense of criminal misconduct.

Even if we accepted that these were the only grounds, which we do not because opinion in the legal community on this is divided, because there are no precedents and because the Convention debates and the authorities we have quoted before are far more divided than the Solicitor-General suggests, and even if we accepted the Government's constricted grounds, which are severely constricted, it is still the duty of no one but this Parliament to examine the relevant material and to make a judgment as to misbehaviour. It is not up to the Attorney -General, the Deputy Prime Minister or the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to tell the Parliament that we have to accept their word. What sort of parliamentary behaviour is that? It is an absolute denial of the role of the Parliament, and the Government knows deep down that it is.

The Attorney-General and the Deputy Prime Minister, despite their difference in years, may belong to a generation of Labor people who have a firm belief that it is the sacred duty of those in power to tell people what is good for them. But we do not. Fortunately the Parliament still has the power to override that arrogant assumption and to assert its own rights, and the Senate is about to assert its rights. It is now up to this Government, if it is fair dinkum, to join with us in a joint committee so that it is not left just to a Senate committee, which is hardly the ideal situation but which is better than the sheer hypocrisy that is going on in denying a joint committee at the moment.

What springs to mind when one thinks of the personal hypocrisy of the Prime Minister's position on this? He has been the man in this Parliament who has been prepared to use illegally obtained material when he considered such use to be in the public interest in 1972. What hypocrisy! Those opposite are the only people who have been able to use, or even wanted to use, such material to destroy another person. The fact is that the Government is presently party to a number of investigations. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking are but two where important work has allegedly been done, as I read what they say, partly by the use of some illegally obtained material. That is not an ideal situation, but it is the reality. Sometimes the use of such material is justified.

I cannot leave this question of authenticity which the Deputy Prime Minister dwelt on for a time without drawing the attention of this House to some recent statements by the Premier of New South Wales. He has recently dropped his accusation that the tapes and the transcripts are fakes. Instead, he is calling for the pursuit of the police and the punishment of the police. The tapes and the transcripts, according to him, have been shown to be sufficiently authentic and he is insisting on the gaoling of those who made them. If they are a fiction , would he be doing that? It is outrageous for the Premier, having determined for himself that the tapes are authentic, now to take on the role of judge and jury without there having been any identification, any charges laid, any trial and with outright besmirching of the police as he sets about the pursuit of those he wishes to incarcerate. But by that action he authenticates the tapes. This question of the authentication of the tapes has dragged on for far too long . Several senior former police officers have stated, and I assume that they are absolutely correct, that the Government could have authenticated them within five minutes, as the Age has claimed it has been able to do. All the argument about authenticity is only a prop again to run away from the reality that is facing the Government, a reality which one House of this Parliament at least will be able to face up to.

The Government has no real justification for its non-action. Indeed, by its inaction, it is putting at risk, to put it mildly, the reputation of the judiciary. Our system of public institutions operates on trust and confidence. Our parliamentary system, our Public Service, our education system and all of our major public institutions can function effectively only in an atmosphere in which the public knows that it is going to get fair and unbiased treatment from those in power. We are not seeing that played out in here. We are seeing a rejection of a sensible move in the Senate for the establishment of a joint committee on the Age tapes. We concur with message No. 181 from the Senate and we will support the Senate in its endeavour to investigate the matter on its own if a joint committee cannot go ahead.

The right to be alone, the most comprehensive of rights and the right most valued by all civilised men . . .
Let me quote further what he said about our rights as individuals:

The makers of our Constitution undertook to secure conditions favourable to the pursuit of happiness. They recognised the significance of man's spiritual nature , of his feelings and of his intellect. They knew that only a part of the pain, pleasure and satisfaction of life are to be found in material things. We cannot say, as one or two people have said to me: 'I don't care, they can tap my telephone. I have nothing to hide'.
