TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I deal firstly with the background. For some years allegations have been made that officers of Telecom Australia have been corrupted by and give assistance to starting price bookmaking. The Connor inquiry into legalisation of casinos in Victoria heard a number of allegations of corruption in Telecom. The Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union and its counsel assisting have also published broad allegations of corruption in Telecom. There have also been allegations by certain individuals extensively reported in the media to the effect that there are links between Telecom and organised crime.

SPEECH.PARA: Law enforcement agencies, the Australian Police Ministers Council and Special Prosecutor Redlich in his 1982-83 annual report, have made criticisms of Telecom for doing less than it should to assist in combating SP bookmaking. The Special Prosecutor has also written to me outlining 'certain disturbing matters' arising from further investigations he has conducted. The purpose of this statement is to report on the outcome of investigations of the allegations of corruption and to set out the basis for action in the future by Telecom to more positively assist law enforcement. The allegations made to the Connor inquiry were referred by me to the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) for investigation by the Australian Federal Police. The Special Minister of State has advised me that:

As a result of a series of interviews and the examination of relevant documents the AFP has reached a tentative conclusion that there is not evidence available which would vindicate in satisfaction of the criminal burden of proof, that there is more than a casual link between organised crime and Telecom.
Organised Crime and SP Bookmaking

The Government has made it clear that it attaches the highest priority to the struggle against organised crime in Australia. The dimensions of the problem have been revealed by a number of recent reports, particularly those of the Costigan Royal Commission and the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking. Illegal bookmaking in itself is a large scale organised crime which provides its operators with large profits. It constitutes tax evasion on a massive scale and is a major source of funds for other aspects of organised crime such as drug dealing. Certainly, the image of the SP bookmaker as the friendly local bloke operating a small business from the pub or club is no longer valid.

Illegal bookmaking is obviously very dependent on the telephone system. Mr Connor in his report observed that 'illegal bookmaking, however, is an industry which at the present time is almost entirely conducted by telephone'. It is thus particularly important that the role of Telecom in assisting law enforcement agencies to detect illegal bookmaking be clarified and set on a firmer basis. Telecom has co-operated and continues to co-operate with law enforcement agencies in the detection of illegal bookmaking. It has provided information on request to police and loaned officers to assist police in their investigations.
Role of Telecom

The prime role of Telecom in the community is to provide an efficient telephone service. Australia has a modern telephone system and use of the telephone has spread well beyond being a luxury item available to few to being a necessity. The very large majority of households possess a telephone; second telephone usage is spreading and a very large number of businesses have needs for multiple telephones, private switchboards, and other modern equipment. Telecom receives a very large number of applications for new and changed services each working day and these must be processed as efficiently as possible. Although Telecom's prime role must be to operate efficiently, this is not to say, however, that Telecom should not have a positive duty to ensure that the telephone system is not being used for illegal purposes. A similar problem arises in a number of government agencies whose facilities are believed to be used by organised crime to assist illegal activities. The Special Prosecutor, Mr Redlich, drew attention to a number of these areas in his recent annual report and criticised agencies for taking what he described as a narrow view of their responsibilities.

In the context of the significance of organised crime and the Government's high priority to its combat, the Government wishes to emphasise that it is part of the responsibilities of all its agencies to take positive steps to ensure that their facilities are not used for illegal purposes and that they provide positive assistance to law enforcement. A narrow view of their responsibilities should not be taken by government agencies. Telecom has indicated that in the light of this clear statement of principle by the Government it will introduce strengthened formal procedures to have its staff report circumstances indicating the use of the telephone network by subscribers for illegal purposes. To establish the basis for Telecom's action, it is proposed to amend the Telecommunications Act to make it clear that Telecom should take positive steps to prevent use of telecommunications services for the commission of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.
Relationship of Telecom and Law Enforcement Agencies

A number of steps have been taken to improve liaison between Telecom and law enforcement agencies. The detailed working arrangements and policy guidelines between Telecom and the Australian Federal Police have been reviewed and revised arrangements are in place. The informal arrangements between the State police and Telecom have also been examined but are regarded as satisfactory and need not be formalised. Formal arrangements have been established in each State and at the national level for high level liaison between Telecom, State police and the AFP. Telecom is taking steps to strengthen its internal investigation unit. The unit has a charter to initiate investigations and pursue them to the point where there appear to be substantial grounds for suspicion. At that point, they will be handed to the State police or AFP as appropriate.

Law enforcement agencies have criticised some Telecom administrative procedures in that they do not provide adequate information to assist in investigation of illegal activities. Telecom, of course, has based its administrative procedures on what it needs to operate efficiently on a commercial basis. However, following discussions between law enforcement agencies and Telecom, it has been agreed that Telecom will collect some additional information from applicants for telephones and will keep appropriate records for a longer period.
Call Record Printers-CRP-Machines

Law enforcement agencies have suggested that it would be of considerable value to investigation of organised crime including illegal bookmaking activities for them to be able to use CRP machines. These machines record outgoing numbers dialled by a telephone user but are incapable of listening to or recording any conversation passed during a telephone call. Their use by police could be of considerable assistance in the detection of organised and systematic criminal activities generally, including illegal bookmaking. The Police Ministers Council has requested the Commonwealth to agree to use the CRP machines for this purpose on a number of occasions.

The use of such machines does raise questions of the privacy of the telephone system. It is the view of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) that use of the CRP machines by other than Telecom does constitute an interception under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act and, unless authorised pursuant to the provisions of that Act, is illegal. While noting that a distinction can be made between an interception which allows the listening into or recording of a conversation and merely recording the number dialled, the Government also notes that privacy issues are involved and any use of CRP machines should be strictly controlled. Noting that Federal and State police forces have urgently recommended that the use of CRP machines be made more available for law enforcement purposes generally, I have asked the Attorney-General to ensure that early consideration be given to this recommendation, and the possible need for amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception) Act, as part of the Government's response to the Law Reform Commission's privacy report. Particular aspects, such as the use of CRP only after issue of a warrant and the imposition of a 'sunset' clause on the relevant legislation, would need to be taken into account.
Letters from Mr Robert Redlich, Special Prosecutor

I have mentioned letters I received from Mr Robert Redlich, the Special Prosecutor, in which he outlined 'certain disturbing matters' he had discovered during further investigation he conducted subsequent to tabling his 1982-83 annual report. Mr Redlich wrote on 17 January broadly outlining these matters and again on 18 January substantiating the issues by detailing case histories. A further letter of 7 March elaborated on two of the case histories. It should be noted at this point that the matters raised by Mr Redlich were not, as reported in the media, allegations of links between organised crime and Telecom and corruption arising therefrom. Rather, the letters set out a number of case histories which indicate policy and administrative practices which, if representative of usual practice, could provide opportunities for criminal elements to corrupt and misuse Telecom, its employees and its facilities. I referred the matters raised in Mr Redlich's letters to the Chairman of Telecom for examination and report to me. Comprehensive reports were subsequently presented to me.

The Government has now decided that the Special Minister of State should ask Mr Frank Vincent, QC, to review the matters raised by Mr Redlich in regard to breaches of the laws of the Commonwealth and impropriety or official misconduct by officers of Telecom. From that review, Mr Vincent is to make recommendations for further investigations by police or Telecom and prosecution or disciplinary action. Mr Vincent is asked further to identify appropriate steps that could be taken to ensure that the facilities of Telecom are not used for illegal purposes , positive assistance is provided to law enforcement agencies and the administrative procedures of Telecom are not conducive to misconduct or impropriety. Mr Vincent is to report by 30 June 1984.
Conclusion

The Government has been seriously concerned at the spread of organised criminal activity including illegal bookmaking and the use of the telephone system for these purposes. At the same time, it is necessary to ensure that the proper efficiency of Telecom is not impaired and that the measures outlined above do not destroy the basic privacy of the telephone system. We believe that the measures announced in this statement preserve this balance. They reflect the Government's commitment to ensure that adequate resources are directed towards the fight against organised crime.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I welcome the statement on Telecom Australia and law enforcement made by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy). The further information he gave today in the statement and the announcement he made recently regarding the approval for Mr Vincent to conduct an inquiry into some of the allegations against Telecom are very important. It is of the utmost importance that the continuing allegations concerning Telecom employees, SP bookmakers, other illegal activities, and the lack of co-operation by Telecom management in pursuing these allegations and in assisting Federal or State police et cetera- they are not only allegations, of course, from Mr Redlich's annual report and subsequent letters-be relentlessly pursued so that those who are engaged in illegal activity can be prosecuted, but more particularly so that the good image of Telecom can be completely restored and maintained. I think that is of tremendous importance to the 90,000-odd people who work for Telecom.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister stated in both his statement today and in his statement of a couple of weeks ago that Mr Vincent is to investigate and report on the points made by Mr Redlich on 30 June. I presume that-I seek the assurance of the Minister on this-any amendments to any of the Acts, whether it be the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 or other Acts, will be made after 30 June when we will have the benefit of knowing the outcome of Mr Vincent's inquiries. I certainly believe that before any of those amendments are presented to this House, debated and voted on it is imperative that the recommendations of Mr Vincent are made public so that they are known to everyone and there is public confidence that what is being recommended is what is required to stamp out this activity and to maintain the good image of Telecom.

However, I wonder whether the action that the Minister announced both two weeks ago and again today would have been taken by the Government if Mr Redlich had not persisted with the three letters following his annual report. He was obviously concerned that no action was being taken by the Government and that certainly there was no change in the attitude of the Telecom management to the recommendations of the report. In my view the leaking of at least one of Mr Redlich's letters has been of tremendous value in seeing that action has been taken. As I said previously, it is important that justice appears to be done as well as being done on behalf of Telecom, which is the largest authority, the largest company, in Australia, with over 90,000 employees. Obviously, amongst 90 ,000 employees there will always be one or two who may not be as honest as the others. But the actions of one or two employees should be no reason for smearing the names of all the employees.

I believe that it is better for Telecom to establish and to maintain a good name by pursuing those engaged in illegal activity rather than by trying to cover up. When one considers that since 1963-this is referred to by Mr Redlich in his annual report-which was the time of the Justice Taylor Royal Commission into Improper Practices in the Postmaster-General's Department in Victoria, allegations have come out time after time. There has been inquiry after inquiry. There is the added concern that not only was Justice Taylor referring to improper practices in Victoria at that time but also that Mr Redlich refers to the fact that once again much of this improper practice is still occurring in Victoria. One has to ask what the situation is regarding the Victorian administration of Telecom.

As I have said and as the Minister has noted, since the 1963 inquiry there has been the Connor Inquiry into the Legalisation of Casinos in Victoria, the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking, the Police Ministers' Council and so forth. I am concerned that the terms of reference for the inquiry by Mr Vincent refer only to the Redlich letters, the Redlich allegations and the Redlich concern about lack of action. Surely, if Telecom is to be completely cleared and its good name re-established, the terms of reference for Mr Vincent must be broadened so that the other allegations can also be considered by Mr Vincent and in particular, the recent Connor inquiry and the allegations concerning the Age tapes. Whether the Government likes it or not, the Age tapes will not go away. They will dog the Government until it deals with them properly.

I note that the terms of reference for the Vincent inquiry state that he can make recommendations for further investigations after considering the Redlich points. I believe that it is important that Mr Vincent have the power, even if not immediately, to broaden his inquiry to take into account, at the same time as taking into account the Redlich points, the other allegations and that he then be allowed to continue to take up those other allegations when he has made his initial recommendations to the Government. I will give honourable members an example of what I am talking about. An article appearing in the Melbourne Age on 16 March refers to Telecom being involved in the New South Wales police tapes. The article states:
The transcripts of New South Wales police tapes given to 'the Age' include references to Telecom employees and links to crime suspects.

In one conversation a Telecom employee talked with the secretary of a crime suspect about connecting a telephone 'urgently tonight' in an illegal Sydney casino. The secretary arranged for the Telecom man to be at the premises about 6 .30 p.m. where another crime suspect would be waiting . . .

The transcripts reveal that the crime suspect, whose business and home telephones were systematically tapped by police in an extensive operation over several months, told a caller that if he wanted anything 'I've got a bloke in the phone company' . . .

Mr Bottom said last night that 15 months ago he gave senior Federal police a copy of the transcripts that detail references to several Telecom employees. Federal police were at that time investigating Telecom matters.

It will be of interest to many ordinary Australians to know that Telecom will connect their telephones for them at 6.30 p.m. on the night they request that service, as at the moment they have to wait weeks and sometimes months to get their telephones connected. I am also concerned that the Minister's statement and rumours that have come from Caucus decisions on these matters have already pre-empted possible decisions and recommendations by Mr Vincent. I quote the headlines of certain paragraphs of what I understand is one of the Redlich letters. The headlines read: 'The involvement of Telecom employees in assisting in the commission of illegal activities'; 'The attitude of senior personnel within Telecom'; 'Lack of co-operation by Telecom staff with internal and police investigations'; 'The employment of staff with serious criminal records and their placement in positions of trust'; 'Interference by senior personnel in internal investigations'; 'The improper use of the disciplinary power under section 58 of the Telecommunictions Act'; 'Reduction in the size of the internal investigation unit'; 'Unsatisfactory working guidelines between Telecom and the Australian Federal Police'; 'The absorption of the internal investigation unit into the Australian Federal Police'; 'The CRP machine'; and 'Creation of a Federal offence of using Federal facilities in furtherance of a State crime'. Those are all very heavy and serious points.

I hope what the Minister has said today in relation to those points will indicate the point I am making about pre-empting possible recommendations. The first is that one of the harshest criticisms of Telecom has been of its failure to treat urgently and seriously breaches of State laws as distinct from Federal laws. I quote from the Minister's statement:

To establish the basis for Telecom's action, it is proposed to amend the Telecommunications Act to make it clear that Telecom should take positive steps to prevent use of telecommunications services for the commission of an offence against a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory.

I realise that there has been uncertainty in the past in relation to what were Telecom's statutory legal responsibilities. But I make it clear that Telecom should take positive steps to prevent the use of telecommunications services for the commission of offences in a State or Territory as well as federally. Is that pre-empting more positive amendments which would require Telecom to treat breaches of State or Territory laws on the same basis as Federal laws? I put that point quite seriously. Will the easier option be taken-that decision has already been made-that would not give Telecom the same requirements? After all, Telecom is the national telecommunications carrier for Australia. It must have equal responsibility for the conduct of the laws of the States of Australia as it does for Commonwealth laws.

In regard to the possibility of pre-empting with a softer option, I refer to Mr Redlich. His last recommendation is the 'Creation of a Federal offence of using Federal facilities in furtherance of a State crime'. In other words, he recommends amending the legislation to create a situation in Australia similar to that in the United States, where it is a Federal offence-and therefore completely within the responsibilities of Telecom-to be involved in any way in using Federal facilities in furtherance of committing a State offence. That recommendation was made by the Special Prosecutor. Does that mean, with regard to the Minister's statement today, that consideration by Mr Vincent has already been pre-empted? I hope not.

The second point concerns call record printers. The Minister noted that there has been pressure for some time from the Police Ministers Council to allow police to use these devices which record telephone numbers but not the actual conversation. The Minister in his statement today made it clear that he has not closed off the possibility of amendments to the Telecommunications (Interception ) Act to allow this to happen. I think he said that the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) has been asked to investigate and report on this matter. But I am worried once again by what could happen if Mr Vincent's recommendation is followed through, having regard to two quotations. The first comes from the annual report of the Special Prosecutor. He referred to the use of CRP recorders as a way of tracking down SP bookmakers, and stated:

It is of interest that in the United States, where there the law also prohibits interception of communications passing over telecommunications systems, it has been held by the United States Court of Appeal, in two separate challenges to the use of such devices, that they do not constitute an interception of communications within the meaning of the United States criminal code. Furthermore, the use of these devices was held to be constitutional in that they did not involve any contravention of the right to privacy and freedom from unreasonable search embodied in the fourth amendment to the U.S. Constitution.

There is a general acceptance that the United States is just as concerned about the rights of individuals as we are in Australia. Mr Redlich referred to the CRP machine as one of the major points in his submission. I quote from that document :
I appreciate that certain proposed broad amendments to that legislation-
that is, the Telecommunications (Interception) Act-

were recently rejected by caucus in favour of a very narrow amendment. However the amendments that I proposed in my report are very narrow and certainly much narrower than those originally proposed by the Attorney-General.

That adds to my concern, the concern of the Opposition and, I believe, of the public generally, that once again because of a Caucus decision-if this information is correct-already anything that Mr Vincent may recommend may have already been pre-empted by decisions which will not allow those recommendations to be accepted. The final point I make on this question of how valuable the recommendations are and how much of the recommendations the Government will be able to take up-because of the fact that it has already made announcements or hinted in certain directions-concerns internal investigation, the Federal Police and Telecom. It has been stated-I think the Minister stated it in his statement today-that Telecom is to strengthen its investigation unit. That is certainly welcome because it is obviously important. In one of the Redlich letters, point no. 7, 'Reduction in the size of the internal investigation unit', states:

The problems I have adverted to are aggravated, at least in Victoria, (I am unaware of the situation in other States) by the depletion of the internal investigation unit. In 1981 there were twenty-one internal investigators within Telecom Victoria. Today I understand that there are approximately eleven. These investigators are responsible not only for investigating criminal conduct associated with Telecom, but they are also required to investigate all civil claims made against the Commission.

The announcement which has been made of arrangements between the Federal Police and the internal investigators means, presumably, that it is impossible for one of the Redlich recommendations to be seriously considered because it has already been pre-empted; that is, 'the absorption of the internal investigation unit into the Australian Federal Police'. The document continues:

I have little doubt that the ideal resolution of a number of these issues is the absorption of that part of the internal investigation unit which conducts criminal investigations into the Australian Federal Police as was originally intended would occur. I said as much in my annual report . . . Suitable members of the internal investigation unit could be transferred to the Australian Federal Police and the balance remain to conduct civil claims investigations.
The argument that criminal activities be investigated by police and not by public servants is overwhelming.

That would appear to me to be a very good solution so that justice would appear to be done as well as being done, by having the Federal Police, as the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Fisher) supports, in their own right working in relation to these illegal activities rather than being there somewhere along the line after Telecom's own internal investigators. Does that mean that one of the major recommendations of Mr Redlich cannot even be seriously considered by Mr Vincent because it has been pre-empted?
I now make the point that Telecom was not the only authority or industry mentioned in the Redlich report. The Minister refers to that matter in his speech. He states:

In the context of the significance of organised crime and the Government's high priority to its combat, the Government wishes to emphasise that it is part of the responsibilities of all its agencies to take positive steps to ensure that their facilities are not used for illegal purposes and that they provide positive assistance to law enforcement. A narrow view of their responsibilities should not be taken by Government agencies.

So, we have Telecom under the spotlight at present. I would hope-and the Minister has made the point-that whoever else is recommended in this report is similarly required to clean up, to justify their procedures-and that is not just government authorities. Banks, for example, are mentioned in this report. One would hope that they have got the message and are motivated enough to be cleaning up the weaknesses in their own systems themselves. It is one thing for all of us to point to Telecom; if we are completely serious as a community, it is another thing to stop at Telecom without looking at the others as well. Where it is not a government authority, it is up to the banks, or agencies or whoever it may be in private industry to clean up themselves.

I appeal to the Minister not to pre-empt any of the recommendations that Mr Vincent may make in consideration of Mr Redlich's points, to allow the investigation to be broad enough to cover all the allegations-if not in the first round, at least in the second round-and to allow public scrutiny of the recommendations before any amendments are made to any of the relevant Acts.

PROCTEXT.PARA: [COGNATE BILL:
SATELLITE COMMUNICATIONS (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1984]
Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate on this Bill is resumed, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill and the Satellite Communications (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1984.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In closing the debate on these Bills, before we move into Committee to deal with the amendments which have been foreshadowed by the Opposition, I should like to thank all honourable members of the Parliament for their contribution to the debate. Members from the Opposition side, particularly members from country electorates, contributed to the debate, and on the Government side I was once again very thankful to have contributions from honourable members from particularly the Communications Sub-Committee who have shown such tremendous interest in this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to deal firstly with some of the matters raised specifically by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). They will be raised in more detail by him later in Committee. It seems to me that there are five particular issues to which the honourable member for Murray adverted in the debate. The first issue was the need for any Telecom Australia subsidiary to be genuinely commercial, and that, of course, relates to the right of Telecom to establish subsidiary organisations. The second point was the agreement that Aussat be prevented from operating a public switched telephone and data service and the confirmation of Telecom as the monopoly public switched telecommunications provider for Australia. We on this side of the House were delighted to hear such a statement from the shadow spokesman for communications. Thirdly, there appeared to be, however, in the minds of those opposite, as expressed by the honourable member for Murray, some concern that Telecom is unnecessarily protected and pandered to in this legislation because, in the Opposition's view, certain unions exerted power over this Government. I shall deal with that matter , as with the others, in some detail later.

Fourthly, the honourable member for Murray also claimed that the Government had tried to forget its obligation to provide through Aussat a free television and radio service, commercially, for people in remote areas. Fifthly, the Opposition still considers that Aussat should be a public company with 49 per cent private shareholding with a majority of government ownership, but it should be noted that the Opposition's proposed amendment does not-although it may have been intended to do so-limit private ownership to 49 per cent.

In respect of the first matter, the need for Telecom to be genuinely commercial -that is, the subsidiaries to be established under the Act-I point out that under the arrangements each subsidiary or joint venture proposed to be set up by Telecom will have to satisfy stringent requirements. Cabinet approval would be required in each case, financing arrangements would be subject to ministerial oversight, and borrowing would be subject to Loan Council approval. These measures are designed to ensure that subsidiaries are not set up for unauthorised or frivolous purposes and to further ensure that the Government at all times maintains control over Telecom's activities in relation to the setting up of subsidiaries. Any subsidiary set up would be subject to the usual commercial conditions applying to similar companies in the private sector. There will be no special or preferential treatment. Telecom subsidiaries would be subject to all Commonwealth and State laws relating to taxation, and Telecom will not be permitted to subsidise the operation of subsidiaries from revenues provided for the public switched network or by the public switched network. Any subsidiaries set up will operate as distinct entities, separate and apart from Telecom, and will not be permitted to use Telecom's facilities or resources to gain unfair competitive advantage over private companies providing similar services. I think that that meets the genuine concerns expressed by the Opposition about this matter.

Further, I should like to make it clear that profit sharing arrangements in respect of the operation of joint ventures and subsidiaries will be subject to government scrutiny. Where Telecom is a shareholder or a partner in a joint venture or partnership, Telecom would be entitled to receive dividend payments in accordance with relevant provisions governing dividend distribution or profit sharing. This in turn will ensure that the services provided under such arrangements will be genuinely commercial in character.

The second matter raised by the Opposition related to the question of Aussat being prevented from operating a public switched telephone and data service and the confirmation of the monopoly position of Telecom. This leads me to a matter of some concern which was raised by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves), a government member. He expressed considerable concern. The honourable member for the Northern Territory disagrees with the interpretation of clause 13 contained in the explanatory memorandum, and I think that it is probably necessary for him again to look at the purpose of that clause and the following clause, clause 14. That is simply to prevent the setting up of a rival service which would bear some likeness to the publicly owned telephony and data network, the public switched network. As far as domestic telephony data traffic is concerned, there is only one common carrier, and that is Telecom. It has always been the objective of the Government to preserve this, and this is why these clauses are in the Bill. In Australia there is only one public switched network. Therefore, the concerns expressed by the honourable member for the Northern Territory about the growth of private networks, while possibly valid in theory, do not in fact have any relevance to the provisions in clause 13.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory is correct in saying that clause 13 prevents Aussat from competing with Telecom in common carrier-like functions, but he did not appear to appreciate that the Bill will allow Aussat to compete in a very limited way by offering private communications services generally complementing those offered by Telecom. Telecom's participation with Aussat will ensure that severe competition with the public switched network is not allowed and we understand, and have been assured over and over again, that Telecom is quite relaxed about such limited competition as might occur, particularly given the dubious economics of running private networks and the availability of satellite transponder space. That being the case, there should be no worries about the cross-subsidisation aspect which was, of course, the other matter which caused the honourable member for the Northern Territory considerable concern. Of course, that is understandable because, as I indicated earlier, other than some with a particular interest in this area, many of the speakers in this debate are representatives of country electorates.

The question of cross-subsidisation being affected was a matter about which the honourable member for the Northern Territory obviously had considerable concern. As I have indicated, I do not see why he has any worries on that point. After all, the great bulk of Telecom's revenue comes from its trunk telephone traffic, that is, traffic carried pursuant to its role as the national common carrier. The Satellite Communications Bill denies Aussat a role as a common carrier in respect of public switched telephone services and public switched data services. I refer, of course, to clause 13 of the Bill.

Other provisions in the Bill, clauses 16(2) and 17(1), constrain Aussat in respect of resale of lease capacity and the establishment of networks that would constitute third party traffic. Within those constraints Aussat's customers will be permitted to operate their own earth stations for both up-link and down-link purposes, and it is expected that the major broadcasters will constitute the majority of users of satellite facilities. Other customers could include major banking corporations and major Press agencies. In the context of Telecom's overall revenues, the diversion of revenues from non-broadcasting users is very small and would have a minimal impact on Telecom's ability to continue its cross -subsidisation of rural and remote subscribers. It should also be noted on this point that much of the traffic to be carried by Aussat for the non-broadcasting users will constitute new traffic; that is, the satellite is expected to generate significant increases in communications traffic. Both Aussat and Telecom are servicing a high growth market. It is also extremely likely that major users of communications facilities will require the design of a mix of Telecom and Aussat facilities in order to take maximum advantage of the flexibility that the two systems offer as an integrated service and to have the added security that it is available in conducting communications traffic. The proposed 25 per cent Telecom shareholding in Aussat recognises this mix of facilities in an overall policy sense; that is, at the Aussat board levels policies can be debated and agreed in recognition of the practical integration of the facilities available from the two organisations.

Finally on this point, it should be noted that, to the extent that Aussat is a profitable enterprise, Telecom will of course derive a 25 per cent dividend payment. In other words, Telecom will be in a position to share in revenues from profitable satellite operations that can be applied to cross-subsidisation of rural and remote subscribers. I hope that that allays the fears of the honourable member for the Northern Territory on that point.

While it is not directly related to the matters raised by the honourable member for the Northern Territory and while we are dealing with common carriers, I would also like to refer just for clarity to another matter. As indicated in my second reading speech, the provision of satellite facilities for use in neighbouring regions does not authorise Aussat to provide services of the type currently provided by the Overseas Telecommunications Commission for communications between Australia and other countries. It is not empowered to compete with Australia's international common carrier, OTC.

The third matter which the honourable member for Murray referred to as causing him some concern was the view I indicated earlier that there seemed to be some unnecessary protection of Telecom and that that seemed to be related to a view that the Government had given into pressure from unions. It ought to be made clear at this stage-certainly the honourable member for Murray would be aware of this, although some other Opposition members might not be-that this Government rejected the recommendations of the Davidson Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia and confirmed the role of Telecom as the common carrier. The purpose of this Bill is to make this position clear. It is not a matter of pandering to unions on the issue as there is no disagreement between the Government and the unions referred to. The issue here is that Telecom remains the common carrier. That is not a matter about which there is any disagreement between the Government and the unions and fortunately, on the basis of some of the comments made in this debate, it does not seem any longer to be a matter of any great disagreement from the Opposition. So it is not a matter of pressure from unions because the views of the Government and the unions on this matter are exactly the same.

There is some difficulty, I think, in those opposite saying that they are not opposed to Aussat being prevented from operating a public switched telephone and data service and then expressing some strange concerns that this legislation is in effect over-protecting the role of Telecom as the monopoly public switched telecommunciations provider, which was the expression used by the honourable member for Murray. Unfortunately, we cannot have it both ways. If that protection is to be given to Telecom, as it will be under this Government, it is necessary to have the legislative framework which is being put in place here.
That leads me to the issue of third party use or in fact more correctly in this case, no third party use. The key words in respect of this very important issue are in clause 17(1) which states:

Subject to the regulations, a person, other than Aussat or an eligible person, shall not use a facility in an Aussat satellite for the purpose of carrying on a business of providing facilities for telecommunication between other persons.

Then the eligible persons are defined in the Bill as the Commission-Telecom-the Australian Postal Commission, the Overseas Telecommunciations Commission or a person declared by the regulations to be an eligible person. A person is thus not prohibited under the clause if the use is not in the course of a business of providing telecommunciations facilities. For example, subscribers to an information service who can provide and retrieve information would not be acting contrary to the clause as the object intended would be not a telecommunciations service but an information provision service. The basic objective of this provision is to give substance to the overall objective of the Bill, expressed in clause 7 as being an intention that Telecom's system and the additional services provided by Aussat together provide Australia's national telecommunciations network and thus provide that restrictions on satellite usage be consistent with those applying to Telecom's terrestrial services.

Section 92 of the Telecommunications Act at this stage, of course, precludes third party trafficking in Telecom's services except in accordance with Telecom' s permission in section 13 or the by-law which preclude third party traffic without Telecom approval except in the case of communications within a common interest group over a system provided by Telecom. Section 94 precludes private services except as provided in section 94(2) which covers government-provided transport and broadcasting services, licensed radio communications and broadcasting services and private communications within the premises of a person .

Clause 17(1) of this Bill adopts the same basic position but allows for exception by regulation. This ensures that the Government, subject to review in Parliament, can regulate the third party policy adopted by Aussat and can examine proposed exceptions to ensure a consistent approach.

In summary, section 17 provides flexibility for the Government on the issue of so-called third party traffic. By regulation the Government may identify a person additional to the existing common carriers who might be exempted from the provisions of the prohibition. However, I wish to make it clear that the Government's present policy is very clear on this point. I cannot currently conceive of circumstances which would see the Government permitting any exception at all from this section other than, of course, the named authorities- Telecom, Australia Post, and the Overseas Telecommunications Commission. Certainly the Government does not propose to permit third party carriage by private organisations.

The other matter raised by the Opposition was the allegation that the Government had forgotten its obligation to provide through Aussat a free television and radio service for people in remote areas. This is not the case. Services to remote areas have not been forgotten. In this instance I am referring, of course, as was the honourable member for Murray, to commercial services. The Government announced its intention to consider a policy regarding broadcasting services to remote areas in 1984. In that statement it was made clear, and I repeat what was said in the statement, that every Australian will have at least one commercial television service potentially available and many will have two or three potentially available. It means just that. Although the fine detail of how it is to be done has not been announced, the Government's intention is to ensure that any Australian will be able to have access to one commercial television service. This minimal level of service would be available to Australians living in single isolated homesteads or in the most remote areas.

In regional areas, that is, the 36 country television areas which exist at present, at least one service and sometimes two will be available through the mechanism of supplementary licences. At some future date it may even be possible to have two supplementary licences, making a total of three commercial services. (Extension of time granted) At some future date it may be possible to introduce those three commercial services and, as indicated, in the major metropolitan areas viewers have up to three commercial services available. I think it is also worth noting that at this stage, and it is an important and significant development, 36 of the 36, that is, the absolute total of regional licensees, have expressed interest in supplementary licences.

The final matter which I think in summary should be dealt with because it is obviously of some concern to the Opposition is that the Opposition still considers that Aussat should be a company with 49 per cent private shareholding and a majority of government ownership. But, as I indicated earlier, it should be noted that the proposed amendment does not limit private ownership to 49 per cent. It is at this point that we probably must concede that there is a total divergence of view between the Government and the Opposition. We on this side of the House, as the Government, have made a decision that Aussat will remain entirely a government enterprise with a 25 per cent shareholding by Telecom. That 25 per cent shareholding by Telecom represents a strategic interest in Aussat, which will enable Telecom to propose up to three directors for appointment to an Aussat board of 13. Telecom would therefore have the opportunity to contribute to Aussat's operational policies at a board level.

Telecom's shareholding also provides for a more effective integration of the satellite system and the terrestrial system, avoiding possible future demarcation issues. That is the essence of the Government's decision to attempt to establish an integrated telecommunications system. It has been our view that to have that integrated telecommunications system we must have both of these organisations working together. We are confident, particularly having regard to the interest which Telecom now has or will have in Aussat, that that aim will be achieved. The closer development of Telecom will facilitate exchange of personnel which could prove particularly useful to Telecom in gaining hands-on experience with satellite technology. It has been indicated, I think to all members of the Parliament who have been interested to discuss the matter, and certainly that applies to the honourable member for Murray, that the Aussat Board is more than happy with the current arrangement and with the involvement of Telecom on that Board. The Chairman of Aussat, Mr David Hoare, strongly favours Telecom's involvement through shareholding. The Managing Director of Telecom, who is already a director of Aussat, has made a very effective input into the Board's deliberations even at this early stage.

That, I think, covers most of the matters of concern which were raised by the Opposition, being those five areas which I have attempted to answer in summary at this stage and the particular problem which was raised by the honourable member for the Northern Territory in relation to section 13 and the issue of cross-subsidisation. I think they are the matters which will be adverted to by the honourable member for Murray when the amendments are moved, and they can be dealt with in the Committee stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 7-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 8 (Obligations of Directors of Aussat).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 8, page 3, at the end of sub-clause (1) add the following paragraphs :
'(d) of a commercial television service for people in remote communities and dwellings in Australia; and
(e) of a commercial broadcasting service for people in remote communities and dwellings in Australia.'.

The amendment concerns the obligations of directors of Aussat. First of all I commend the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) for a very comprehensive summary of the debate that took place almost two weeks ago. It is slightly unreal after a delay of two weeks to move back into the debate, but he certainly put forward the arguments from the Government's point of view.

On the point of obligations of directors of Aussat, the Opposition feels that the fourth criterion, that is, those things that the directors of Aussat should take into account as far as practicable to meet the requirements for the use of a satellite, is very important. The Government has deleted the fourth criterion which we believed in government and believe in opposition was of equal importance. Clause 8 refers to air navigation facilities, to the requirements of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for the provision of television and broadcasting services to remote areas and to the provision by Telecom of telephonic services in remote areas and emergency services. Our amendment proposes fourth and fifth criteria, as we distinguish between radio and television, being a commercial television service for people in remote communities and dwellings in Australia and a commercial broadcasting service for people in remote communities and dwellings in Australia.

The point here is that members of the Opposition believe, and when we were in government we were putting into practice our belief, that it is the right of every Australian to have and not potentially have-this is the distinction between ourselves and the Government-not just an ABC radio and television service but a free commercial radio and television service when those satellites go up. Then with the introduction of RSTV all Australians will have a third program choice, and that is pay television. Aussat is the way to achieve the right for all Australians, particularly those in remote areas, to have two types of television and radio services, and that is a commercial service and an ABC service. The whole basis of the original planning of Aussat, the domestic satellite, was for that purpose.

Honourable members will recall that there were going to be four zones with the high powered transponders on the second satellite, or the mix between the two satellites on spot beam to cover Australia with a free commercial service. Will it be by using the third satellite and the high powered transponders on that satellite if it goes up safely in 1987 or whatever year, to allow decoders for certain areas but not for other areas with all the problems of additional cost and pressure with no coding of those national signals going out for the networks, or for allowing general direct broadcasting? The purpose of the amendment which I have moved is to keep before this Government and the people of Australia the original intention and purpose of Aussat and to see that the promises to the people in the remote areas of Australia are carried out.

Instead, we now have an Australian Labor Party Government in power doing what the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia should have done over the last 20 years. They sat on their butts and did nothing. They are now hypocritically claiming the credit for this system.

When the communications sub-committee of the Caucus sat we had representation after representation from networks, regionals and other operators saying: 'Would you please clear up the mess that the previous Government created in the communications field? We do not have a clue what is going on. There is no policy . There is confusion, confusion, confusion. The satellite was going to do this and the satellite was going to do that. The previous Government did not have a clue what it was talking about. It just left us in a confused position because it could not work out a policy on communications'. Why could it not work out a policy on communications? Because it did not have a clue. That is exampled by what has happened here tonight. The honourable member for O'Connor does not have a clue. Most of the people opposite who have spoken during this debate, except for the Opposition spokesman in this area, do not have a clue either. Only one or two members of the Opposition have a clue. At least they speak some sense. But the honourable member for O'Connor does not have a clue. The previous Government did not have a clue about it. That is why the networks, the regionals and other operators such as the Myer and the IXL groups came to us time after time and said: 'Please clear up the confusion'.

We have been in power for one year. In that one year we have set about clearing up the confusion. We have confirmed the launch date for the satellite. We have set about the process of first of all offering the regionals an opportunity to expand their services. They have indicated that they will do that. We will look at the people who are not covered by a commercial service once we know exactly which people are covered by the regional service. We will then consider the options to provide those people with, first of all, a service; secondly, a choice of programs which would not be provided under the system suggested by the honourable member for O'Connor; and, thirdly, a free service, that is, an advertiser-based service. We will look at all of those options when we have found out what area the regionals intend to cover.

We are quite used to hearing the honourable member for O'Connor in this chamber misrepresent, tell untruths and talk nonsense. It is not an uncommon occurrence. He did exactly that by deliberately misrepresenting what I said when I spoke earlier in the debate. I did not say that the people of the Northern Territory should not have commercial television. I went into some detail about how they will get commercial television under this Government's final decision and policy . The clarity of that policy has existed since this Government came into power, which is the exact opposite of the mess and confusion which were created by the hillbillies opposite.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us get to the point made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in regard to commercial television in the outback. I confirm the remarks made by the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Saunderson) who was spot on and by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) who is a very good honourable member and who has on numerous occasions spoken in this place and elsewhere on behalf of the people of the Northern Territory regarding commercial television. He has spoken studiously on behalf of the people in his constituency . The idea put forward by the Opposition, which the honourable member for O' Connor is asking us to agree to, as I said earlier, is for a consortium. He is asking us to set up a commercial consortium which, as the honourable member for Deakin said, would have 30, 40 or 50 members. Who would have control of it? Three to four major networks and all the regional networks would be involved. Those which had the major say in that consortium would be the major networks, not the regional networks, as the honourable member was implying.

That is what the suggestion is all about. That is what Neil Brown tried to do and failed to bring together several years ago. Honourable members opposite may argue about words and the other things they have argued about during the last hour or so, but the idea behind this suggestion is to set up a commercial consortium to go on the second Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service satellite. That will not work. Neil Brown realised it was a failed proposition because all the links just did not fit together and they will not fit together now. This Government, as I said earlier, has clear policies that have been put forward. The honourable member for Deakin has articulated those quite well. Honourable members will see that those policies will come forward and that every person in Australia will have the opportunity to see commercial television as well as Australian Broadcasting Corporation programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

The Directors of Aussat shall ensure that, so far as practicable-
we have even had that spelt out-
Aussat is able to meet the requirements for space facilities, satellite facilities.

(a) of the Commonwealth for the purpose of the provision and maintenance of air navigation facilities . . .

Does that mean that the Commonwealth, for its air navigation facilities, will be granted that transponder space free or on something less than commercial terms? But somehow or other it is a giveaway against Aussat; somehow somebody will get something for free, for less than commercial rates. (d) of a commercial television service for people in remote communities and dwellings in Australia.

The same applies in regard to radio. What does that say, other than that the Aussat directors have to take into account that if there is a commercial proposition they provide that facility. Government members are saying that they will provide a commercial service for people in remote areas. The honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves) waxed quite indignant about this, as did the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Saunderson). Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members can disagree. That is fine. They can disagree that we would have been further down the track. But what the Government is doing by saying that is agreeing with our amendment, that it could put a commercial service into remote areas better than we could. That is fine. If the Government believes that, what is the argument about? Why does it not support the amendment , because we are both saying that the people in remote areas of Australia have a right to a free commercial television and radio service. On that basis I appeal to the Minister to support the amendment because if one is to believe the speeches and interjections made by some of the speakers on the Government side in relation to this amendment, they are saying not only that there will be a free commercial service to people in remote areas but also that they will do it better than we could have if we had been in government. That is fine. They have a right to believe that. We do not believe it, but what they are saying is that they believe that such provision will be made. So let us all get together on this matter, confirm what Government members are alleging and saying, and support the amendment. I appeal to the Minister to think in the terms of the moderate wording of this amendment.
—Ha, ha!
—The honourable member does not know what the word moderate means, but the Minister does. We could all agree on the priorities, where practicable, for Aussat.

It appears to me that the matters raised tonight, particularly by the honourable member for Murray, which were put in a low key when compared with the somewhat provocative comments made by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) really indicate that the old Homestead and Community Broadcasting Satellite Service II proposal, as has been pointed out by members on this side, is still around in the minds of honourable members opposite. SPEECH.PARA: The other matter which disturbed me a bit was the fact that there seemed to be some indication from the honourable member for Murray-it must have been given to him by somebody in the industry-that there was some sort of threat by this Government in respect of the regional television stations, that they had to come up with some proposal. I assure him that that is not so. They had discussions with the Department and also I had long discussions with representatives of regional television in Melbourne late last year and again early this year. It was pointed out to them that this Government was looking at the various options that were open to provide commercial television to remote areas in Australia. They have not come forward and I can understand why, because the difficulties in relation to that proposal are no different now to the difficulties the Opposition faced when in Government. The old HACBSS II proposal is an extremely difficult proposal, with the commercial service on zonal beams and the difficulties with it are no different now than when the Opposition was in government and are unlikely to be different. But I still remain open to persuasion on that point, if it can come forward with something fairly quickly, or come forward to Aussat with some proposal in relation to it. But it does not appear that anything is forthcoming at this stage.

One matter raised by the honourable member for O'Connor concerned the proposal he mentioned with regard to the Western Australian Government. That proposal is a matter that is under consideration at present by this Government. It is one that cannot be easily dismissed. It is a proposal which must be given serious consideration. There is no doubt about that and it will be given serious consideration. But I repeat one thing that I said earlier in this debate; that is, that every Australian will have at least one commercial television service potentially available. Many will have two or three potentially available. That means just that. The question that was raised of potential rather than certainty is answered by the fact that we want to try to get it right. This matter has gone on for a long while now and when the decisions are made they ought now to be made in the atmosphere of some calmness. Some decision should be made which will work for those people who have been so cruelly deprived of those facilities for far too long.

I must say that the point made by the honourable member for the Northern Territory is well made in the sense that when we came into government, despite all the criticisms that may be made quite justifiably by the Opposition-that is its role-there were more decisions taken in this area when we consider the period we have been in government and what went on prior to our taking office. The previous Government was no closer to a decision on this matter than it was in 1977 because of the difficulties in putting together that consortium that the Opposition seems to be returning to now in the discussion. That is a very difficult operation and probably almost impossible.

When this matter was first discussed in November last year, the honourable member for Murray expressed his concern that remote areas had been forgotten. He put forward then that one of the reasons that the ministerial statement was deficient was primarily that it foreshadowed further statements on supplementary licences, radiated subscription television and commercial television services for remote areas. In respect of that criticism, it should be noted that papers on the first two matters have been issued and the Government will address the question of remote areas after the report of the satellite programming service inquiry, which has remote areas as a specific term of reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about RSTV?

—That is one of the areas which the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is directed to examine as a specific term of reference. Those proposals have been discussed by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations and the other members of the industry. Thirdly, the honourable member has just raised by way of interjection the proposals regarding RSTV services. At this stage the Government has not made a decision on RSTV, which I have indicated. What we have done at this stage is to call for proposals in relation to it, and they will be examined within the next three to five months. That is the period in which we shall be looking at those proposals as they come forward. No decision has been made by the Government with respect to whether they should be commercial or ABC. We have an open mind on that matter because we want to be able to examine the proposals from both sectors.

SPEECH.PARA: However, having had a short lecture by the honourable member for O'Connor on statutory interpretation, I think that we ought to have a look at clause 8 of the Bill. The background of that is that the provisions of clause 8 are designed to ensure that public interest aspects of satellite transmission are met. It applies to only the television remote services. No other particular protection is provided to the ABC there. There is a requirement in sub-section 1(b) relating to the ABC, which states:
. . . for the purpose of the provision by the Corporation of television and broadcasting services to remote communities and dwellings.

That is the primary object-to ensure that that public interest aspect is met. But that public interest requirement is limited there to television and broadcasting services to remote communities. The first section of the clause provides that Aussat must provide facilities for the Commonwealth:
. . . for the purposes of the provision and maintenance of air navigation facilities and related safety services.

The provision of services by Telecom in that clause relates to the provision of telephonic services in remote areas and emergency services. So clause 8 is designed to ensure that the public interest aspects of the satellite transmission are met. The amendment proposed seeks to place commercial broadcasting on the same level as public interest priority, above government organisations. It is not appropriate for that objective to be enshrined in legislation in the same way--

TALK.START.PARA: —We just feel that it is.

—The honourable member is entitled to feel that, but in regard to clause 8 what I am saying, on behalf of the Government, and the reason why the amendment is not acceptable, apart from the various other discussions that we have had, is that that clause is designed to ensure those public interest aspects which I have just mentioned. In my view, it is not appropriate for that objective to extend to commercial broadcasting.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that the Government is aware of the desirability-everyone has said it here tonight-of commercial broadcasting being available to the remote areas. We are examining the best ways in which that can be done. Decisions on that matter should be available shortly after July this year, so it is not a matter that is being left on the long finger. It is being addressed almost daily at present. Despite the constant carping criticism from some honourable members opposite in relation to this Government and country electorates and the alleged lack of concern for them, it is just not true. We have an absolute commitment to provide the service that those people have been denied for so long and that they deserve to have. For those reasons, the Opposition amendment is not acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make just one comment on the point made by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) about threats to television stations. I wish to quote from today's Australian Financial Review. An article headed ' Television and the satellite' states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: All this of course still leaves the remote areas without a commercial television service.

There are groups prepared to supply, at a price, a commercial direct broadcast service to the Outback. Mr Duffy has asked the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations to bang its members' heads together to find a way of serving isolated areas . . .

It is the feeling of many that the consortium approach is still to be attempted. Clause 11 concerns the ownership of Aussat Pty Ltd, in particular whether or not Telecom Australia should have 25 per cent of the shares of a company which will continue to be a private company completely owned by the Government. Therefore, I move:
Clause 11, page 3, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
'11. (1) Shares in Aussat are not capable of being held by any person other than-
(a) the Commonwealth;
(b) a person as trustee for the Commonwealth; or
(c) such non-statutory corporation, entity, or person as may be prescribed.
(2) Each share in Aussat shall be issued with the same rights and restrictions with regard to voting.

(3) No shares in Aussat can be sold or transferred unless a statement of the proposed sale or transfer has been laid before each House of the Parliament and the proposed sale or transfer has been approved by resolution of each House of the Parliament.
(4) Any issue, sale or transfer of shares, or any arrangement or agreement, that is contrary to this section is void and of no effect.'.

The purpose of this amendment is to retain Aussat as a private company with the shares completely owned by the Commonwealth without any shares held by Telecom. We move it simply because we believe it is not appropriate or necessary for Telecom to be a shareholder. In the second reading debate I made the point that if it is logical for Telecom to be a shareholder because of an allied interest or use, it is logical for Australia Post to be a shareholder in Telecom or for Trans Australia Airlines to be a shareholder in Qantas Airways Ltd and so forth. It is correct, as the Minister pointed out, that it is the Opposition's policy that Aussat eventually have the majority ownership in a public company owned by the Commonwealth with up to 49 per cent of the shareholding sold to the private sector. The Opposition is quite relaxed as to when this should take place. In fact the actual intention of the amendment is to retain the ownership completely by the Government of Aussat as a private company. I fail to see why the Government should be upset by that sort of amendment.

If there is any criticism by the Government that somehow or other there is a rush from our side to convert Aussat to a public company with a private shareholding percentage, it is completely incorrect because there is no reference in my amendment to pushing that issue. If there is to be any criticism of anybody with regard to converting Aussat to a public company with 49 per cent held by the private shareholding community, the criticism should be directed at the Treasurer (Mr Keating) because he indicated in the mini-Budget of May last year that that would happen. If one looks at the Budget Papers one will see that the Treasury even allowed for that in this financial year. So let us not hear any more rot about rushing to convert Aussat to a public company, because only one person publicly stated his interest in doing that, and that was the Treasurer.

The amendment I have moved provides for the power over the future ownership and the arrangement of that ownership to remain completely with the Government. That power is not to be taken out of the Government's hands. I am quite amazed at the bluster that some honourable members on the Government side have used in relation to this issue, amounting almost to blackmail. The only way in which I can logically consider this situation is either to conclude that it is just bluster or to ask who is running the Government in this area. Is it the Government itself or is it a particular union?
Government members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask honourable members opposite to listen to this. I listened to them. Let us get one thing quite straight. If honourable members opposite really believe in democratic institutions I suggest that they listen to me also. The whole basis of the bluster by some Government members that if somehow or other we were opposed to Telecom having no percentage, and that therefore the whole lot would be given to Telecom, is really absurd. It is based on four absurd assumptions. If honourable members opposite follow them through logically I hope they will understand what they have really been saying. Firstly, for them to make that bluster or that threat, they must really mean that Telecom is the ultimate horrible, nasty organisation that it is possible to inflict on the people of Australia. It is honourable members opposite who are saying that.
—It is you who are saying that.

—I ask the honourable member to listen. I listened to him. We are not at a union meeting; we are in Parliament. Both sides have the right to be heard, which is not the case in some of the organisations to which the honourable member obviously belongs. He is not prepared to listen to somebody from the other side putting his point of view as I listened to him when he put his point of view. It is honourable members opposite who have been making the threat about Telecom, not us. One of the logical assessments to be made from that is that honourable members opposite are threatening that, somehow or other, giving complete ownership to Telecom if we do not agree to its getting 25 per cent is about the worst thing that can be inflicted on the people of Australia. That is a terrible insult to Telecom, and the Opposition completely dissociates itself from it. But that really is the logical implication of the threat that some honourable members opposite have made. It is inaccurate and it is unfair to a great national organisation. It is an insult to Telecom for honourable members opposite to have made that threat.
