We certainly agree that Telecom should be represented on the Board of Aussat.

SPEECH.PARA: The second absurd implication of the tactics that some honourable members opposite have been adopting is that somehow or other the Opposition is more powerful than the Government and that the Government is not able to make a decision unless somehow or other the Opposition refrains from putting an alternative point of view. If the Government has been honest in its claim that it will give Telecom 100 per cent if we do not agree to the 25 per cent, why is that the case? It has nothing to do with the Opposition because the Government has the numbers. It must be the result of outside pressure on the Government in relation to this issue. Only the Government knows what the real position is, but that certainly is the implication from the threats that it has been making. The real significance and the absurdity of the threat by certain Government members is that it makes a nonsense of the claim by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that a Labor Government can handle the unions. Here we have a government that is more or less bowing to unions on this issue and we are told that somehow or other it can better obtain the co-operation of the unions. The Government's whole track record in this area and the threats made indicate that the opposite is the case.

The third logical implication of the bluster from the other side on this point is that we must question what this type of tactic means for the Government in general. If every time the Opposition dares to oppose the Government on any issue the Government by its own definition then threatens something worse, the conclusion must be that the Government has no firm policy on an issue, only a range of options in descending order of threat and that it comes in at a particular level depending on our opposition. If it is logical to say that if we do not agree to Telecom getting 25 per cent the Government will give Telecom 100 per cent, does that mean, for example, that if we do not agree to an assets test -the assets test and meat inspection charges are two other issues on which the Opposition has been disagreeing with the Government-the Government will hurl a capital gains tax as well as an assets test at us? Does it mean that if we do not agree to meat inspection charges at the exorbitant rate that the Government is threatening at the moment the Government will double that threat by a 100 per cent recovery? I ask honourable members opposite just to think through what the logical implications of that bluster are. If they are logical and that is a consistent policy for them as distinct from the result of some sort of outside pressure, that is the logical follow-through in other areas of policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was your policy on the meat inspection levy-user pays.

—An interesting point has been made by interjection. Had we been in government there would have been no increase in meat inspection fees. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) agrees that there should not have been. I suggest that the honourable member talk to his own constituents in the Northern Territory. I suggest that he tell them that the Minister for Primary Industry agrees with the Opposition that there should not have been an increase but that, because of the overwhelming numbers of people in the Labor Government who do not care about rural areas, that increase was imposed on them. If I were the honourable member, in future I would be a little more careful before I interjected on a subject like that, because he cannot win on it. I return to the third point. As I said earlier, if it is correct for Telecom to have 25 per cent of the shares in Aussat because of its great use, it is correct for all these other cross-ownerships to take place.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Saunderson Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to a couple of points. Once again we have seen the Opposition's intransigence in accepting that this Government has looked quite logically at what is required. There is no doubt that in order for Aussat Pty Ltd to perform at its peak and in order to ensure the proper development of the national communication network, there is a requirement for an extremely close relationship to be developed between Telecom Australia and Aussat. There is no doubt that the best way for that to be achieved is for the two to be involved in Aussat together. That is why the decision for Telecom to have 25 per cent of the shares has come into being.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), in his speech in the second reading debate, used some examples to show why he thought that this was a ludicrous idea. He mentioned things like Australia Post having part ownership of Telecom and Trans Australia Airlines having part ownership of Qantas Airways Ltd , all of which are totally irrelevant extensions of the argument. The fact is that the satellite and the current terrestrial network will both be involved for the first time in the same area of endeavour. The examples that the honourable member gave relate to totally different fields of endeavour and therefore his whole argument is absurd. He also argued that the $21m that was to be expended could be spent by Telecom in other areas. He obviously has not looked at the Government's decisions, otherwise he would have known how that money was to be raised and what it was going to do. In fact, Telecom will be able to raise $21m above its normal borrowings. It will be purchasing the Government's interest in Aussat. That will provide the Government with an extra $21m which it would otherwise have had to keep tied up in Aussat. That $21m will be able to be used in areas of more urgent need in which the Government is involved.

Once again, as in the previous speeches by the Opposition, the argument about union control has come out. In some absurd way, the Opposition's belief that the Government has made the decision for the satellite to go ahead and that Telecom should have some interest in Aussat has been tied to some proposition that this Government has been controlled by the unions. More importantly, the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) has tied it particularly to one very small union in Telecom-the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association. Let us look at the facts as they have been perceived many times by honourable members opposite. The Opposition has put forward the case that the ATEA was opposed to the satellite going up, that it argued vigorously against the satellite going up . The Opposition has even said that the ATEA argued to the current Government that the satellite should not go up. Supposedly, we have been controlled by that organisation in the decisions we have made. If so, how come we have arrived at the decision that the satellite should proceed? That decision is directly against what the Opposition said the union has supposedly been putting to us. Given that the argument was supposedly put by the ATEA, it clearly shows that in that instance we have gone in exactly the opposite direction. The ATEA has spoken out in areas, for instance, in relation to access by broadcasters to the satellite. If we look at the submissions put forward by ATEA and then at the decisions made by the Government we see once again that our decisions were exactly opposite to its submissions. How can it then be said that we are being controlled by the union?

If we look at the ownership issues of Aussat we find once again that we have gone on a different tack to that which the union has proposed. So in all of the major areas where submissions have been put in we have differed in our decision from the submission which the union has put to us. Members of the National Party of Australia have another debate going on. Obviously they are not interested in the satellite and its services to the community, but we are all here. They are reminiscing about the old days when they were in government. Let me make it quite clear that any suggestion that the unions within Telecom or the ATEA in particular are controlling the decisions made by this Government is ludicrous in the extreme. Any proper examination of submissions put by that union and decisions made by the Government will clearly show that to be indisputably a fact. I hope that members of the Opposition will drop that ludicrous argument that they have been trotting out every time.

The real situation is that Australia currently has a national communications network of which it deserves to be proud. The only way to ensure the continuing development of that national communications network in the way in which it has developed in the past is for the direct involvement of Telecom in the Aussat company. We have done it to an extent where no one can argue that Telecom has become the overbearing part of the corporation. It has a 25 per cent interest. As has been explained by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy), it will have four of the 13 directors which will ensure that whilst it has a voice it will not have an overbearing voice. At the same time the interests of the terrestrial network will be preserved as against those of the satellite network. More importantly, it will mean that for the whole of Australia the development of the network will serve all Australians equally; those in the outback, those in the suburban and regional areas, those in industry, those in commerce and those individuals such as community people who wish access for their individual private use. We have ensured that in the way in which we are going ahead.

What would happen if the amendment were carried? There would be a development of competition. Even though the two organisations might still remain two public enterprises it would be difficult for the directors of both Telecom and Aussat not to see themselves in some way in competition, to be trying to compete and to provide equal services. That would not be for the betterment of the Australian public. Telecom having a 25 per cent interest will ensure, first of all, that Aussat will be developed to its maximum because Telecom will have a pecuniary interest and, secondly, that it will protect the total communications network as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The supreme apologist, the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Reeves), will not give up. SPEECH.PARA: The other point that is made, and I think the honourable member for Deakin mentioned a figure, is that Telecom Australia is getting special rights to raise $21m and, therefore, that will not affect its expenditure in other areas. But even if that is not the case, and I cannot affirm that, why is it necessary to let Telecom borrow $21m to invest in an area where nobody really wants his money when it has failed to deliver to the Australian public absolutely decent telephone services? I am not even talking of a service to the middle of the Northern Territory. Clearly the honourable member for the Northern Territory would be worried about that. He would be worried that his constituents got too many good things. He would worry about that. He is the second 'Life was not meant to be easy' fellow. He keeps going back to the Northern Territory and saying: 'Fellows, life was not meant to be easy'. I am sure that he has learnt something.

The facts are that, even if he does not want this service, where it is expensive, for those people who probably, sensibly, will be provided with a service from Aussat Pty Ltd or from one of the digital arrangements that Telecom is coming up with, what is wrong with some people who live 200 miles from the city of Perth getting a telephone exchange that at least is up to date? Last Wednesday in the town of Kulin I had people telling me how inadequate their 1948 model exchange was. It is inadequate today; let us face it. Twenty one million dollars could go to buying them a new telephone exchange, for which they would be grateful. Admittedly they have telephones. It is an inadequate service.

If nobody else wants the money, and Telecom has to be allowed to raise additional borrowings to invest in the Aussat arrangement, why could it not first meet its commitment at Kulin? I know that the regional officers, the workers of Telecom, would be thrilled to bits to have some of that money to meet that commitment which would create employment in that arena. It is like what happened when the Premier of Western Australia invested $50m in a mining project . Not one job was created from that $50m investment. I would say that not one job will be created by Telecom investing $21m in Aussat because it is money that other people are willing and able to provide.

I have a funny feeling that, as much as the honourable member for the Northern Territory tries to talk his constituents out of it, they would think that a good telephone service provided by Telecom would suit them fine. All sorts of people got all nervous and jumpy when the previous speaker from this side, the shadow Minister for Communications, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), mentioned some unions. SPEECH.PARA: Let us take this bit by bit. Let us take that clause first. It allows 100 per cent private ownership no matter what the Opposition says. I will not be as kind as the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in his rounding up of debate on the second reading speech when he said that this may have been unintentional. I believe it is deliberately intentional to put that in the clause so that at a time when it pleases the Opposition it can put the proposition forward to the people of Australia that it should sell the whole of Aussat off to private enterprise. I will just pick up the very last point that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) made in regard to the power behind the Australian Telecommunications Employees Association, or any other union, business, company or corporation in this country. If we are selling it off we are not necessarily selling it off to two or three people. We are selling it off to anyone. I have a basic principle: No matter who that person is or who those persons are it is dreadfully wrong in the extreme to sell the entire communications of a country. In the decades ahead we will be looking at the satellite.

The honourable member for O'Connor has espoused the wonders of the satellite which will become more evident as the decades progress. Yet the Opposition is proposing this amendment to sell the entire communications satellite system off- that is what the amendment provided-to private enterprise. Therefore, the communications in this country will not be owned by the people of Australia as they should be. In a crisis, such as a defence crisis, which is why most countries do not sell off their communications to private enterprise, a government does not have control if the entire satellite system of a country, which will be the major component of our communications in three or four decades , is in private hands. Of course one could romanticise about the hands they may be in. I am quite sure the Opposition would jump very quickly if, for example, Laurie Carmichael decided that he would take up a few shares in Aussat Pty Ltd as against Kerry Packer. If it is sold to private enterprise it is sold to anyone, whether he is to the left or the right. I believe a basic principle is involved. No matter who they are we do not sell the communications of a country off into private hands. That is what this amendment is all about and that is why this Government will reject it out of hand.

The honourable member for Deakin quite succinctly put at rest the nonsense that the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) talked about in regard to the union situation. It is quite nonsensical. The former right honourable member for Richmond in his heyday talked about the unions, union bashers, the socialists on the horizon, and that they were charging to disrupt the country and the unions, et cetera. But all that has gone. It has passed by honourable members of the Opposition. They are all men of yesterday. Why do they not wake up to the situation? People do not buy that rhetoric any more. The honourable member for Deakin pointed that out quite succinctly. The competition that honourable members are talking about we will probably get to in the next clause, clause 17. But just to reiterate, we will talk about fair competition when the Opposition moves the next clause because there will be plenty to talk about in answer to the honourable member for O'Connor who talked about clause 17 on competition and not clause 11. As I said, the amendments to clause 11 put by the Opposition take the ownership of a satellite system in what is a fairly major new step for Australian communications and what will become a very major part of our communication system.

As far as we can foresee at present, that situation probably will be enhanced as the decade continues. That ownership is to be taken out of the people's hands and put into private hands. Although the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has stated that that ownership will be up to 49 per cent, the true intention is not in the amendment. The figure of 49 per cent is not stated in the amendment, rather it needs:
such non-statutory corporation, entity, or person as may be prescribed.

One person can own all the shares under such an amendment. One person could own 100 per cent of the shares. As I have already stated, it is quite clear that the Opposition, if it came to power, would do just that. Whether the Opposition did it straightaway or at some foreseeable time in the future, that is what the amendment says. That is not what the people of Australia want. Historically or traditionally that is not what the Australian people want. It is not what good governments around the world require of their communication system, which is one of the most important aspects of any society. The people of Australia should have control. Under this Government's proposals the people of Australia do have that control. Under the proposals put forward, 75 per cent will be owned by the Government and 25 per cent will be owned by Telecom Australia-not the Australian Telecommunication Employees Association, as the honourable member for O'Connor said earlier. He said that the ATEA will have so many of its members on the board. That will not be so. I hope that Telecom will have so many members on the board, not the ATEA as the honourable member said in his closing remarks.

Telecom will be on the board because of the integration of what is a very good telecommunication system in this country. It represents the integration of a terrestrial system and a satellite system which will mean that Australia will have one of the best telecommunication systems in the world. For all those reasons, the Government supports the legislation as put forward and rejects the amendment out of hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise only to confirm the fact that the argument over ownership of the satellite and Telecom Australia's participation in ownership of the satellite is indeed over. It is not over just because the Opposition benches were entirely empty when the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said a moment ago that honourable members from the Opposition benches could one day achieve government. The argument is over because this Government is finally bringing the satellite to the people of Australia and is putting it in the hands of the Australian people. That is why the argument is over. The Australian people will be so pleased-they already are-that the satellite will belong to them.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is one thing I cannot understand it is this fear and horror of the participation of Telecom Australia. It is not a question of there not being competition; it is a question of there being co-operation among the people best qualified to have anything to do with the satellite. On the one hand we have the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) talking about our unnecessary protection and pampering of Telecom, on the other hand we have him talking as if we were threatened by Telecom. The fact is that this Government, in the interests of the most effective functioning of a satellite, is bringing Aussat Pty Ltd and Telecom together to work co-operatively.

Telecom has a greater expertise to bring to this satellite than anyone else in this country. Telecom Australia has developed a telecommunications system which is of the highest quality by international standards. The frequent application of new techniques has been of importance in this regard. Communication satellite systems basically perform the same functions as terrestrial communications carrier systems, to transmit messages by electronic means between two or more points.

Prior to the development of the satellite communication systems the carrier systems employed by Telecom Australia, and before it the Postmaster-General's Department, underwent substantial technological changes. More and more sophisticated cables were developed and applied. We have also seen the development of more sophisticated microwave systems and digital radio concentrator systems for telephone services in remote areas. All the time it has been Telecom providing this and progressing in this way. Next is the application of fibre optic cable and digital transmission techniques-two further changes at early stages of application. In a very real sense the application of geo- stationary earth satellites is part of this continuing pattern, a pattern where the expertise has been developed by Telecom for so long. It is for that reason that it is necessary that Telecom is part of the communications system. It is for that reason that co-operation between Aussat and Telecom will be to such an advantage. I am tired of the Government being accused of pampering, over- protecting or succumbing to the threats of Telecom when the Government is faced with an Opposition whose first interest in the satellite was to give it to its powerful friends. That was the whole point of the former Government's interest in it in the first place. It was not for the public good but for the private profit of its friends and backers. The Opposition is not denying that, and everyone knows where it all began.

It was proved earlier tonight that a consortium would not work because it never has worked. However, the fact is that individuals in the media game can be powerful enough to take it on themselves. It has come to our attention today that News Corporation Ltd is poised to commence direct broadasting of commercial television in the United States of America and the United Kingdom. This is at a time when the British Broadcasting Commission's plans to introduce direct broadcasting have been thrown into confusion by a dispute with the Thatcher Government and technical standards. News Corporation Ltd probably regards itself as more powerful than either of the conflicting parties in that dispute. Mr Murdoch has said:
We are thinking of direct broadcast satellites as something that will fill in where cable TV cannot go.

We cannot convince the people of Australia that a man of the unabashed power and ambitions of Mr Murdoch would not try to take on this on his own if a consortium could not be formed. Certainly Aussat will be making a profit, and Aussat will be interested in profit for the people of Australia. That is why I still cannot understand the objections to either public ownership or more importantly Telecom 's participation in the ownership of Australia's satellite.

When the Opposition was in government it conducted a reign of terror against Telecom; it persecuted it into the ground, bled it dry and left it moribund for when the Government eventually arrived on the scene. It is because of that reign of terror, that persecution, that Telecom is in a position in which the honourable member for O'Connor complains about archaic exchanges. The fact is that the previous Government was more interested in persecuting Telecom than in making sure it was able to provide a service to the people in remote areas such as in the Northern Territory and the electorate of O 'Connor. Of course the former Government was too stupid to realise that it was also attacking cross-subsidisation which meant that the people in the bush got a substantially cheaper service than if they had to pay on a user pays basis. The dries, people such as the honourable member for O'Connor, who apply user pay principles, do not tie up the question of cross-subsidisation and user pays. TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence recently heard submissions from the Department of Defence and the Department of Defence Support. These had been prepared in writing by both departments and had been lodged. The submission from the Department of Defence Support had been lodged as long ago as August 1983. We do not know under whose authority it was lodged.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that some days ago and apparently just hours before the Senate Committee was to hear evidence from the Department and receive its submission formally into the evidence, the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Howe) crossed out certain parts of the submission, leaving the parts that he crossed out still there. We know that what the Minister or his Department said in that submission was in irreconcilable conflict with what the Department of Defence said in its submission. Let me just read to the House what the Department of Defence said in its submission on the subject of Australia's defence co-operation with South East Asia. In its submission of February 1984 the Department said:

The overall defence co-operation program is conducted for mutual benefit and while it assists in introducing the Australian defence industry to the region, it is not and has not been encouraged to become an arrangement for promoting the sale and export of Australian produced defence equipment.
Whether one agrees with that proposition or not, that is what the Department of Defence said. What did the Department of Defence Support originally say in its August 1983 submission? It said:
The Department of Defence Support submits that the development of defence co- operation arrangements with Australia's near neighbours can be of benefit to Australia in two ways:
this was deleted-
as a means of strengthening the technological dependence of countries in this region on Australia and hence their strategic value to Australia in the event of an emergency.
Then it went on to develop what could be done in the stimulation of Australian industry. It said, and this was also crossed out:

One way in which this stimulation could be achieved could be for Australia to become a more active exporter of defence materiel, services and technology to those countries in its region which it sees as long term, close allies.

One would have thought that that was a fairly sensible proposition, but that was crossed out. The two submissions cannot live together. I would like to ask the Minister for Defence Support some questions and since he is in the House he can answer them. Who authorised the submission of August 1983 to be made? Did the Minister read it? Did he know it was being made? Why is there that basic conflict between his Department and the Department of Defence? Why did the Minister remain in ignorance between August 1983 and a few days before the hearing earlier this month of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence of what was in his own Department's submission? How could this possibly be so? How could that submission have been prepared contrary to his views? If it was prepared contrary to his views, as most evidently it was because he went to the effort and took the last minute decision of crossing out parts of it, how did that happen? Who is in charge of his Department? Is he in agreement with his departmental views? Is he in agreement with the views of his departmental head? What are his views on the subject? Does he stand by the thrust of the submission that his Department originally made? Will he tell us in direct terms the reason for the changes that were made? TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme, or IPTAAS, as it is known. I think this scheme is a great innovation and helps many people, particularly those in isolated areas, who normally would not be able to afford to obtain top class medical attention. I wish to draw to the attention of the House the case of Mr Ainslee Rook, a friend of mine who lives in Broken Hill. Ainslee is a boilermaker. Unfortunately, Mrs Rook, Ainslee's wife, has cancer. In order to obtain treatment she has to travel to Adelaide. Ainslee came to see me and spoke about the forms that have to be filled in for IPTAAS. Because of the type of medication and attention that his wife has to receive, apparently the doctors have some trouble in filling in these forms. I believe the form that is presently available-I have a copy here-would be mark III. I think there is only one more difficult form and that is the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance form which one needs a PhD to fill in.

SPEECH.PARA: Ainslee has to take time off to take his wife down to Adelaide to attend the Queen Elizabeth Hospital. They have to go by aircraft, as the journey is 500 kilometres. On arriving in Adelaide, first of all Mrs Rook has to attend the Department of Hematology and Oncology. From there she goes on to have an echo scan of her heart, then to the Department of Nuclear Medicine for a radioactive scan and then to the ward for chemotheraphy. This is all very traumatic, but no doubt many other people in Australia have to attend these different departments in different capital cities. The trip to Adelaide takes one night and two days. The air fares total about $362 and the accommodation about $75. Taxi fares total about $30 and lost time as a boilermaker amounts to about $140.

The big problem with this form is that, with so many people involved, when the doctors go to fill in the form-it takes a bit of filling in-they invariably fill it in incorrectly. After Mr Rook has sent the form away it comes back from the department concerned with a request for more information or advice that it is not filled in correctly. There is always something wrong. I am putting to the House a suggestion that comes from Ainslee Rook. Perhaps it can be sent back to the appropriate department to be looked at in the hope that a more simplified version-perhaps a mark IV I think it would be-could come out to help people like Ainslee Rook.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take a few minutes this evening to put the New South Wales elections that were held last Saturday into a little more perspective than we have seen in the newpapers in recent days. There is no doubt that the result last Saturday was an excellent victory for Neville Wran and the New South Wales Branch of the Australian Labor Party. Of course, we have to listen to some of the bleatings of the Opposition and listen to some of the bleatings in the Sydney newspapers. What those papers say, of course, does not equate at all with the result. We have an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of this week which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Saturday's vote (particularly in the Sydney metropolitan area) was a warning to the Government to lift its game.
In the news page of that same newspaper we have Ross Dunn saying:
A significant result of the State election was the huge protest vote against the Wran Government which has transformed once-safe Labor seats into marginal or semi-marginal electorates.
That, of course, is absolute rubbish. Let us have a look at what the same newspapers said in 1983 after the magnificent Hawke victory. The Sydney Morning Herald said in an editorial:

The swing to Labor is impressive in all States except Tasmania. Although it is most pronounced in the metropolitan areas, it is apparent also in the rural areas of Queensland, N.S.W., Victoria and Western Australia.
In the news pages of the same Sydney Morning Herald of 7 March Paul Kelly says:

In N.S.W., Labor performed well, winning seats in both city and country. The N. S.W. result was better than many Labor figures anticipated and is a reflection of the traditional and underlying strength of the ALP in Australia's biggest State.

One would think, from reading those two editorials and those two news items, that there was a markedly different vote in New South Wales in 1983 from the vote in 1984. But the facts, of course, absolutely put the lie to this calumny that is being put around by the Opposition. In the Hawke Government victory in 1983, the Australian Labor Party's first preference vote in New South Wales was 50.1 per cent. In figures that I have asked the Parliamentary Library to prepare for me today, it is estimated that the Labor first preference vote in the election last Saturday for the Wran Government was approximately 50 per cent; very little difference altogether. But that is not the impression we get from reading the newspapers or from listening to the bleatings of the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock). If we listen to them we would think there was some phenomenal rebuff last Saturday. But the Sydney Morning Herald in its editorial and news pages, talking about the same figure of 50 per cent in March 1983, indicated that it showed a significant victory for Labor. We now find that the same figure-50 per cent-in March 1984 shows a significant failure for the Labor Party.

Of course, one might then say: 'Let us look at some other indicators in New South Wales elections to see whether Neville Wran is doing well or whether he is doing poorly'. One way in which people measure whether governments are successful or not is by the size of their majority. Let us look at the size of the majority of the Askin Government, the only successful Liberal Government New South Wales has ever had, if one takes time as being an element of success. Askin was the Premier of New South Wales for 10 years, up to the present the longest serving Premier in that State. But what was the best majority that Bob Askin had when he was Premier of New South Wales? His best was a 12-seat majority in 1968. That was the best that the Liberals could ever do-a 12-seat majority in 1968. But if we listen to the honourable member for Dundas and some of his supporters, Neville Wran did terribly badly. He is on the brink of disaster. What is Neville Wran's majority in 1984? It is 17 seats. If that is a loss I hope that we lose the next Federal election to that degree because I am sure that the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would not mind a 17-seat majority in this House. I am sure that the Labor governments in other states of this country would be happy to lose an election if the majority that they had was a 17-seat majority.

I think that by any stretch of the imagination the result in New South Wales last Saturday was a magnificent victory for the ALP and a magnificent defeat for the National Party of Australia who went backwards further and further. Nick Greiner can look at himself with only a 32 per cent vote now compared with a 36 per cent vote his predecessor had as the Leader of the Liberal Party in 1976. If that is what honourable members opposite call a victory for the Liberal Party of Australia I can only wish them many more victories in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the comparatively short time available to me I briefly want to canvass the law as to the admissibility of evidence which is illegally or unlawfully obtained. One only has to look at the authorities in Archbold, going back to 1861 in Leathem's Case-there is a long and continuous thread of authorities, approved as recently as 1955 by the Privy Council in Kuruma's case-to recognise that there is no doubt at all, as a matter of law, that the method of which evidence has been obtained is strictly irrelevant. Therefore, as the authorities have shown, evidence which has been stolen is admissible and evidence obtained by an illegal search is admissible subject only to the question of whether or not the judge has a discretion to exercise to exclude the said evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: The case that I want to refer to specifically, which is referred to in Archbold , the 40th edition, at page 1408, is the Queen v. Ali and Hussain in 1965, 2 All England Reports page 464, in the Court of Criminal Appeal. In that case the police used a tape recorder to eavesdrop upon conversations between two prisoners. The evidence was admitted. The method of the informer and of the eavesdropper is commonly used in the detection of crime. The method of taking the recording cannot effect admissibility as a matter of law although it must remain very much a matter for the discretion of the judge. In the case of the Queen v. Mills and Rose, reported in 1962, 3 All England Reports page 298, the Court of Criminal Appeal and again in Senat's Case 1968, 52 as Criminal Appeal Reports it was held that recordings of conversations obtained through telephone tapping by private individuals should be admitted in evidence. The point that I want to make is that the New Zealand authorities support that proposition, as do the Canadian.

I condemn the hyprocrisy of those who have stood in this Parliament and claimed that such would not be the situation in Australia. I challenge the Government to state publicly whether or not it is aware of a decision that has become of considerable importance, reported in 38 Australian Law Reports, the case of the Queen v. Migliorini and Others in the Supreme Court of Tasmania, in the exercise of Federal jurisdiction. That is a case in which telephone tapping was carried out by a police officer in breach of the provisions of the Telecommunications ( Interception) Act 1979. Commonwealth law was breached but the Court exercising Federal jurisdiction admitted the evidence. The judge, His Honour Mr Justice Cosgrove, quite clearly stated that a court might well receive evidence in the form of limited broadcasting of a record made illegally. I am appalled that in this Parliament it is being claimed on behalf of the Government that such evidence is not admissible.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could have appealed it if they thought it was wrong.

—Of course. The plain fact is that there is a Federal jurisdiction decision in relation to the taping of a conversation in respect of criminal proceedings and tapes obtained in breach of the Commonwealth legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to reply briefly to a series of questions-I do not know that there was much more to it than that-addressed to the House by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender). It ill becomes, I would have thought, the conservative party in this House to raise the whole question of defence co-operation and defence sales or indeed defence industry. I would have to say that I inherited in my Department an area in which, despite the enormous emphasis placed by conservative governments and their rhetoric, various establishments suffered enormous neglect . I think that neglect is such that the question of export sales of defence equipment for the most part has been a somewhat academic question.

SPEECH.PARA: While the various factories and establishments in the Australian context have been able to service in many ways the defence forces in Australia, I believe extremely adequately, they have certainly not been geared up to play any major role in relation to export markets anywhere in the world let alone within our own immediate region. If one is talking about the sale of defence products to developing countries, one must raise that Australia certainly has not made any kind of significant contribution in that area. In 1980-81 we sold something like $2.95m worth of defence related equipment and supplies to developed countries including those in our own region; in 1981-82, $1.2m; and in 1982-83, $1.8m. We are talking about a very tiny amount of activity in terms of any kinds of exports to developed countries including those in our own region.

The reason that I made some changes in the departmental submission, and I make no apology for that, was that it seemed to me that the departmental submission was trespassing into areas of policy which were properly matters for the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes). In that sense I think the part which was a policy statement added nothing to the submission. I removed what I thought were in many respects some misleading statements. I refer particularly to the reference to the creation of the situation of technological dependence within the Asian region. I think that that statement could be interpreted as reflecting an insensitivity which could be certainly misunderstood within the region. I wanted to ensure that that misinterpretation was not possible. So a change was made in the document, particularly to remove that emphasis and to remove emphases which I felt might well cause people to be misled.

There is no question that the Department of Defence Support operates within the policy established by the Government and particularly policies which are primarily defined by the Department of Defence. The Department of Defence Support is primarily responsible in relation to defence industry, the management of the various factories and establishments and the liaison with private industry in Australia. Our role in terms of defence co-operation is extremely limited; our role in terms of export sales has been an extremely minor role in the past. That role has not been defined so much by this Government but has been defined historically by those governments which preceded us. If members of the Opposition are concerned about what has not happened they have to take prime responsibility.

I think it is important with respect to defence sales as opposed to defence co- operation that one recognise the sensitivities of the particular issue. I think it is a concern, hopefully to people on both sides of the House, that we have seen in many respects in recent years a growing militarisation of the Third World. We have seen quite substantial increases in military spending in many of the Third World countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. If no other Minister rises, he may continue for a further period of five minutes.

—I thank the House. I think that that issue is certainly a cause of concern. In terms of selling defence equipment or defence munitions or stores within our immediate region, I think we do need to exercise considerable caution . I have never suggested that those sales ought not to take place. Quite the contrary. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 30 November 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the New Zealand Government's Clinical Services Letter No. 222 of 14 September 1983 to Medical and Dental Practitioners and Pharmacies, recommending small fluoride doses where administered by tablet because of widespread use of fluoride toothpaste and because of the possibility of some mild enamel opacities.

(2) If so, is he able to say whether (a) the new dosages amount to half the former recommended dosage for children under 4, a quarter for those under 2 and nil for those under 6 months in areas with less than 0.3 ppm fluoride ion in water supplies, (b) the circular advises neither for nor against fluoride tablets for nursing mothers, their infants or infants under 6 months of age because there is no proven benefit to them, and against use of fluoride tablets in pregnancy because of no proven benefit and general inadvisability of unnecessary tablets during pregnancy and (c) the circular advises no more than 5mm of toothpaste, small pea size, for young children.
(3) What plans has the Government to establish any benefit of water fluoridation to pregnant and nursing mothers and infants under 6 months of age.
(4) What advice does the Government offer to pregnant women in water fluoridation areas whose existing children show enamel opacities and who wish to avoid such disfigurement in future children.
(5) At what age does the Government recommend that fluoridated toothpaste be used, and in what quantities.
(6) Do Australian manufacturers of fluoride tablets recommend those doses recommended by the New Zealand Government; if not, why not.
(7) What doses of fluoride tablets are advisable for homes whose water supply contains 0.3 ppm fluoride.
(8) Are free assessments of fluoride concentrations in domestic bore water obtainable, at intervals, on application to local health authorities.

(9) Is he able to say whether 1981 statistics for the greater Auckland area, show more children's dental decay in fluoridated than unfluoridated parts of Auckland but not to a statistically significant degree.

(10) Is he able to say whether Auckland's principal dental officer and president of the New Zealand Society for Dentistry for Children, Mr John Colquhoun, advised Auckland parents not to let pre-school children use fluoride toothpaste and claimed that preliminary inquiries suggest about one Auckland child in 4 in fluoridated parts of Auckland and one in 25 in unfluoridated Onehunga could have had teeth damage by white flouride mottling and in severe cases discolouration, pitting and enamel breakdown, reaching an unsightly stage in one in 50 in the fluoridated areas but none in unfluoridated Auckland.
(11) Will similar surveys be attempted in Australia using double-blind studies, where patients and assessors are unaware of the water supply fluoride concentration.
(12) What advice is available to patients and practitioners seeking confirmation of the cause in a case of enamel mottling.
(13) Will he take steps to prevent television advertising of fluoridated toothpaste showing several centimetres of toothpaste on a toothbrush.
(14) What public funding is available or proposed for capping teeth made unsightly by fluoridation of public water supplies.
(15) Will the Government support parents who sue toothpaste manufacturers for damage caused by young children swallowing fluoridated toothpaste.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, the New Zealand Department of Health has advised that there is no evidence of any increase in incidence of dental fluorosis in New Zealand.

(2)(a) The daily fluoride supplements recommended in September 1983 by the New Zealand Department of Health for use in areas where the water supply contains less than 0.3 part per million of fluoride are shown below: 6 months-2 years, 0. 25 mg; 2-4 years, 0.5 mg; 4-14 years, 1.0 mg.
The previously recommended dosages were: Birth to 3 years, 0.5 mg; 3-12 years, 1.0 mg.
(b) Yes.
(c) Yes.

(3) There is no need for the studies referred to by the honourable member. While there is overwhelming evidence for the effectiveness of fluoridation of water in the control of dental caries, it has been generally accepted that the use of fluoridated water during pregnancy and lactation does not affect dental health of the child.

(4) As only minimal development of the permanent teeth occurs during pregnancy the use of fluoridated water during this period would not be a factor in the causation of minor opacities of these teeth. The use of fluoridated water during childhood does not cause dental opacities of aesthetic significance.

(5) The Government has never made recommendations concerning the use of fluoride toothpaste at various ages, or the quantities that should be used. However, dental authorities recommend that brushing using fluoride toothpaste should commence at approximately twelve to eighteen months. The quantity of toothpaste used at each brushing has not been defined.

(6) No. The manufacturers of fluoride tablets in Australia are guided by the recommendations of the National Health and Medical Research Council with regard to daily dosage. The Council is re-assessing the recommended dosage in the light of recent developments.

(7) A precise recommendation has not been made by the National Health and Medical Research Council concerning the level of fluoride supplements in cases where the drinking water contains 0.3 parts per million of fluoride. The National Health and Medical Research Council currently recommends that in non- fluoride areas the following daily fluoride supplements be taken by children: 0- 12 months, 0.25 mg; 12-24 months, 0.5 mg; Over 24 months, 1.0 mg.
(8) This is a matter for State health authorities.

(9) I have not been able to obtain these statistics. However, the New Zealand Department of Health has advised that children living in areas of New Zealand where the water is fluoridated have better dental health than children living in non-fluoride areas.

(10) I understand that Mr Colquhoun did give the advice referred to by the honourable member. However, Mr Colquhoun's statements have not been accepted by the New Zealand Department of Health which, in collaboration with the New Zealand Fluoridation Advisory Committee, the New Zealand Dental Association, the University of Otago School of Dentistry, and the New Zealand Plunket Society, has recommended the fluoridation of water, the use of fluoride toothpaste and the use by children of fluoride tablets if the water is deficient in fluoride.
(11) In view of the available evidence there is no necessity for the studies referred to by the honourable member.

(12) A patient seeking information about mottling of the enamel should consult a dental practitioner. The practitioner who requires additional information concerning dental mottling could approach a State health authority or a University dental faculty.
(13) The use of fluoride toothpaste by children has been referred to the National Health and Medical Research Council and consideration will be given to this matter when advice is received.
(14) Fluoridated water at recommended levels has not been shown to cause defects in teeth necessitating the provision of dental crowns.

(15) The question is hypothetical. While fluoride toothpaste has been sold widely in Australia for some twenty years, I am not aware that any parent has sued a toothpaste manufacturer for damage allegedly caused by swallowing fluoride toothpaste.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government given detailed consideration to the implications for Australia of Article VI(a) of the Statute of the International Atomic Energy Agency, which requires that the designated member of the Board of Governors of the IAEA for each region, be the member country most advanced in the technology of atomic energy, including the production of source materials.

(2) Has the Government obtained advice, in particular on (a) the effect on Australia's current status as a designated board member of the IAEA for the South East Asian and Pacific region of different scenarios for the development of Australian uranium mining and export over the next 2 decades, and (b) whether Australia stands to lose its Board membership in the event of the Government deciding to phase out uranium mining and export over the next 2 decades: if so, (i) could Australia secure its position under the provisions of Article VI(a) by increased research activity in such areas as waste disposal and medical nuclear technology and (ii) what country or countries in the region would be likely to displace Australia from the Board and what type of nuclear program would Australia need to pursue in coming years to secure its position as the most advanced country in the region.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Membership of the Board of Governors of the IAEA is determined by Article VI of the IAEA Statute. Amongst other things that article indicates that membership of the Board comprises:
(1) As designated by the outgoing Board of Governors-
(a) the nine member states most advanced in the technology of atomic energy including the production of source materials,

(b) the member state most advanced in the technology of atomic energy including the production of source materials in each of the eight designated regional areas (identified in the statute) not represented by one of the nine most advanced;
(2) 22 members elected by the General Conference in accordance with the criteria for regional representation provided for in the article.

Since the inception of the IAEA in 1957 Australia, which is in the South East Asia and the Pacific region, has been designated rather than elected as a member of the Board. Membership of the IAEA Board of Governors has assisted Australia to play a prominent and constructive role in international consideration of issues relating to the peaceful uses of nuclear energy, including international safeguards. The Government will continue to give active support to the IAEA and its important task of verifying that the development of peaceful uses of nuclear energy under IAEA safeguards does not lead to diversion of nuclear material to nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. Australia's continued membership of the IAEA Board of Governors is seen by the Government as a valuable contribution to the work of the IAEA. It is also a major means by which Australia can advance non-proliferation goals in accordance with the Government' s very strongly held conviction that there should be no further spread of nuclear weapons or nuclear explosive devices to additional countries.

The Government has therefore given detailed consideration to the provisions of article VI of the statute of the IAEA and will continue to monitor international developments as they might affect Australia's designated position. While it would be inappropriate to speculate on possible future developments in this regard, Australia's role as a significant exporter of uranium is clearly of particular importance.

The Slatyer inquiry is examining all aspects of Australia's involvement in the International Nuclear Fuel Cycle. That inquiry, and the examination of its outcome will necessarily include, inter alia, considerations of the sort raised in part (2) of the question.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Com- munications, upon notice, on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action is he taking to ensure that print handicapped radio is available to as many disadvantaged Australians as possible.
(2) What are the current problems in achieving this aim.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government is acutely aware of the needs of handicapped people who cannot see, handle or comprehend the print media. This includes not only the blind and partially sighted, but also many of the aged and those who are illiterate. My Department is presently undertaking a review of Radio for the Print Handicapped (RPH) services with regard to their licensing, funding and future development in Australia.
(2) There are two major problems associated with the development of RPH services throughout Australia-

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Alleged Staff Reorganisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 8 December 1983 :

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the editorial in the Age of 5 December 1983 ; if so, (a) is it a fact that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is reorganising 1300 members of its staff, (b) is it a fact that there will salary increases for those 1300 staff members as a result of this reorganisation, (c) what is the (i) extent and (ii) range of these increases, (d) will staffing levels increase as a result of this reorganisation and (e) will any salary increases gained as a result of these changes disturb salary relativities within the ABC; if so, to what extent.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to reported expressions of incredulity and mindlessness by the Government and some members of the new ABC Board at this proposal.
(3) What steps will he take to ensure that the best interests of the public purse are safeguarded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question based on information supplied by the ABC, is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes.

(b) A submission has been made by the ABC to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission requesting that a new salary scale be approved by an anomalies conference. If approved, most but not all of the 1300 staff involved would receive an increase.
(c) (i) The salary structure being sought involves increases ranging from $20 to $700 per annum with 56 per cent of those affected gaining less than $400 per annum.

(ii) Existing salary ranges are equivalent to the proposed new range but the intention is to produce four salary barriers, which will only be passed by successfully completing courses and having work skills assessed.

(2) No such expressions have been reported to me.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 8 December 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will he ask the Australian Embassy in Manila to monitor the operation of Australian companies in the Philippines to ensure that these companies comply with Philippine labour laws and with the standards of the International Labour Organisation; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian companies operating as private commercial undertakings in a foreign country are subject, no less than private citizens, to the laws of that country. This is particularly so regarding laws framed to guarantee certain basic levels of observance of fundamental and universally recognised human rights. I am informed that in the Philippines, a wide ranging labor code seeks to perform this function in the area of industrial relations, supported by the operations of the Philippine Ministry of Labor and Employment.

The enforcement of Philippine labour law is clearly an internal matter for the Philippine authorities. At the same time Australia's reputation regarding our commitment to observance of universally accepted standards of human rights and to conformity to the rule of national justice is an important aspect of the Government's foreign policy. Accordingly, the Australian Government maintains an interest in the activities of Australian companies in the Philippines. As evidence of this interest, I refer the honourable member to my reply to Senate question on notice no. 343 (Hansard, 3 November 1983, page 2242).

With regard to the standards of the International Labour Organisation, the Philippines has ratified 21 ILO conventions. These include conventions covering workers compensation, a minimum age for industry, the abolition of forced labour , protection of wages, and the right to freedom of association and protection of the right to organise. Adhereance to these conventions is subject to regular monitoring by established machinery within the ILO itself.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon D.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 29 February 1984:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to proposals for amendment to the Antarctic Treaty to (a) promote observer participation in, and access to documents and information from, Treaty conferences (b) implement the 1983 Non-Aligned Movement resolution that the exploration of the Antarctic and the exploitation of its resources shall be carried out for the benefit of all mankind with global revenue-sharing which would place the area in a similar legal category to the high seas and seabeds and (c) establish a minerals regime to base any decision regarding minerals development on a high threshold standard of environmental impact assessment for Antarctica and under the Law of the Sea Convention; if so, is it the intention of the Government to pursue these proposals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of any specific proposals for amendment to the Antarctic Treaty. However, Malaysia took the initiative both at the 1983 Non-Aligned Summit and at the United Nations General Assembly of challenging the Antarctic Treaty system, claiming principally that it was exclusive and secretive, and that the benefis of any resource exploitation in Antarctica should be shared amongst all mankind. The 38th session of the General Assembly adopted by consensus a resolution calling upon the United Nations Secretary-General to prepare a comprehensive factual and objective study of all aspects of Antarctica, taking fully into account the Antarctic Treaty system and other relevant factors, and to report to the 39th session. Australia will cooperate in this study. It will argue strongly that the Antarctic Treaty system offers the best means of preserving the demilitarisation of the continent and of promoting international harmony and cooperation now and in the future.
In regard to the specific questions raised:-

(a) At the 12th Antarctic Treaty Consultative Meeting (ATCM XII) held in Canberra in September 1983, contracting parties which are not consultative parties were invited for the first time to attend as observers. The consultative meeting decided to encourage the widest possible circulation of information about Antarctic activities and to send the report of ATCM XII to the United Nations Secretary-General.

(b) The Non-Aligned Summit resolution on Antarctica suggested that the exploration of the Antarctic and exploitation of its resources should be carried out for the benefit of all mankind. It made no reference to 'global revenue sharing'. Its operative section called for a comprehensive study of Antarctica by the United Nations Secretary-General which, following the 38th section of the United Nations General Assembly, is now in train.

(c) Talks are in progress between Antarctic Treaty consultative parties aimed at producing a minerals agreement which would govern any future minerals prospecting, exploration and development in Antarctica. The minerals regime is to be developed in a way which will not prejudice the interest of all mankind. The talks are at an early stage. The Government considers that any minerals agreement must contain stringent environmental safeguards.
